<ref name=":4">O’Haire, M. E., McKenzie, S. J., McCune, S., & Slaughter, V. (2013). Effects of Animal-Assisted Activities with Guinea Pigs in the Primary School Classroom. Anthrozoos, 26(3), 10.2752/175303713X13697429463835. http://doi.org/10.2752/175303713X13697429463835</ref><ref name=":3">Meadan, H., & Jegatheesan, B. (2010). Classroom Pets and Young Children: Supporting Early Development. YC Young Children, 65(3), 70-77. Retrieved from http://www.jstor.org.libezp.lib.lsu.edu/stable/42730602</ref>{{Multiple issues| {{essay-like|date=August 2018}} {{original research|date=August 2018}} {{Orphan|date=August 2018}} }}
'''Classroom pets''' are animals that are present in an educational classroom as a pet.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Daly|first=Beth|last2=Suggs|first2=Suzanne|date=2010-02-12|title=Teachers' experiences with humane education and animals in the elementary classroom: implications for empathy development|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03057240903528733|journal=Journal of Moral Education|language=en|volume=39|issue=1|pages=101–112|doi=10.1080/03057240903528733|issn=0305-7240}}</ref> Research and literature over the past decade, has shown the main reasons for having classroom pets is to capture the attention of students, improve relationships, provide the opportunity for creative activities, be a resource for humane education, and act as a motivator for students.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Correale|first=Cinzia|last2=Crescimbene|first2=Lara|last3=Borgi|first3=Marta|last4=Cirulli|first4=Francesca|last5=Correale|first5=Cinzia|last6=Crescimbene|first6=Lara|last7=Borgi|first7=Marta|last8=Cirulli|first8=Francesca|date=2017-11-27|title=Development of a Dog-Assisted Activity Program in an Elementary Classroom|url=http://www.mdpi.com/2306-7381/4/4/62|journal=Veterinary Sciences|language=en|volume=4|issue=4|pages=62|doi=10.3390/vetsci4040062|pmc=5753642|pmid=29186915}}</ref>
== Educational impact ==
In 1987, The National Institute of Health reported evidence on the health benefits of pets and further studies have shown positive effects from children’s relationships with pets.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Poresky|first=Robert H.|last2=Hendrix|first2=Charles|date=1990-08|title=Differential Effects of Pet Presence and Pet-Bonding on Young Children|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.2466/pr0.1990.67.1.51|journal=Psychological Reports|language=en|volume=67|issue=1|pages=51–54|doi=10.2466/pr0.1990.67.1.51|issn=0033-2941}}</ref> It has thus been assumed that similar benefits would present themselves with classroom pets on students.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Ganzert, R. R., & McCullough, A.|first=|date=2015|title=Pets in the classroom study: Phase I findings report.|url=http://site.americanhumane.org/Resources/PETS%20IN%20THE%20CLASSROOM%20CKT%20R4.pdf|journal=American Humane Association|volume=|pages=1–39|via=}}</ref>
=== Social-emotional development ===
Classroom pets can support young children's social-emotional development.<ref name=":3" /> Classroom pets help build positive relationships through discussions about classroom pets, such as what to name it, and how to care for it, and then working together to do so.<ref name=":3" /> This also aids in the development of friendships within the classroom.<ref name=":3" /> It has been found that students develop a sense of caring about others other than themselves through tending to the needs of the animals in the classroom.<ref name=":3" /> It has also been seen that discussions about the behaviors of the animals in the classroom, what they mean, and what the students can do about it can help students become empathetic towards others.<ref name=":3" /> Teachers have claimed that classroom pets also teach children the value of routines and rules. <ref name=":3" /> One study compared students in a classroom with class pets to one without for 8 weeks.<ref name=":4" /> The study found that both parents and teachers reported that the students in the class with the guinea pigs had greater increases in social skills and decreases in behavior problems at the end of the 8 weeks.<ref name=":4" /> These results support similar previous study results.<ref name=":4" />
Young children's interaction with classroom pets can also help them manage feelings and emotions. Research has shown that children need an empathetic listener whenever they feel troubled. Children can be encouraged to share their feelings with their animals if they do not want to express them with an adult.<ref name=":3" /> A study surveying 75 elementary teachers, revealed that most teachers believed students displayed an increase in compassion and empathy when pets were used in the classroom.<ref name=":0" /> Additional findings have shown that classroom pets, not only improve compassion and empathy but also teach children to have respect for the living things in the world around them.<ref name=":2" />
Classroom pets can also have a positive effect on the socio-emotional development of students with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). After engaging in animal-assisted activities for 8-weeks, children with ASD displayed an increase in social skills and a decrease in social withdrawal.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=O'Haire|first=Marguerite E.|last2=McKenzie|first2=Samantha J.|last3=McCune|first3=Sandra|last4=Slaughter|first4=Virginia|date=2014-03|title=Effects of Classroom Animal-Assisted Activities on Social Functioning in Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder|url=http://www.liebertpub.com/doi/10.1089/acm.2013.0165|journal=The Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine|language=en|volume=20|issue=3|pages=162–168|doi=10.1089/acm.2013.0165|issn=1075-5535|pmc=3948601|pmid=24156772}}</ref>
=== Academic development ===
Teachers conveyed that classroom pets contribute to the academic development of students and have identified pets as important sources for students. They have found them to expand learning and increase development.<ref name=":0" /> Academic lessons, ranging from science to language arts, have been enriched by this valuable source and have improved academic competence among students.<ref name=":2" /> Classroom pets create an object of observation and research for children during science class. Children will learn how to care for the animal, what it eats, and what type of surroundings it needs to live. Science can also be linked with language arts using classroom pets. Students can write books and create presentations from their research. Students academic skills in math also increase by having a classroom pet. Students can measure its physical attributes and how quickly or how far it moves using graphs or charts (Benham, 1991, p.21).
<ref>Benham, Dianne C. “A Short Stay, A Long-Lasting Lesson.” Science and Children, vol. 29, no. 3, 1991, pp. 19–21. JSTOR, JSTOR, www.jstor.org/stable/43170127.</ref>
=== Increased teacher awareness ===
Through the use of a Dog-Assisted Activity Program in a multi-cultural elementary classroom, researchers found that teachers are more aware of student difficulties and strengths after interacting with dogs. After engaging with dogs, it was found that students expressed emotions and displayed behaviors more clearly, helping teachers recognize student qualities that were hidden prior to the dog-assisted activity.<ref name=":1" /> This suggests that the presence of classroom pets does not only benefit students but also results in increased teacher awareness. Despite these results, survey research shows that only about 17% of elementary teachers have classroom pets.<ref name=":0" />
== References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Pets]] [[Category:School and classroom behaviour]]

{{Voice type}} A '''contralto''' ({{IPA-it|konˈtralto}}) is a type of [[classical music|classical]] female [[singing]] [[human voice|voice]] whose [[vocal range]] is the lowest female [[voice type]].<ref name=McKinney>{{cite book |title= The Diagnosis and Correction of Vocal Faults |last= McKinney |first= James |year= 1994 |publisher= Genovex Music Group |isbn=978-1-56593-940-0}}</ref>
The contralto's vocal range is fairly rare; similar to the [[mezzo-soprano]], and almost identical to that of a [[countertenor]], typically between the F below middle C (F<sub>3</sub> in [[scientific pitch notation]]) to the second F above middle C (F<sub>5</sub>), although, at the extremes, some voices can reach the D below middle C (D<sub>3</sub>)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.voiceteacher.com/contralto.html |title=Training the Contralto Voice |last=Jones |first=David L. |date=2007 |website=The Voice Teacher |accessdate=2018-07-24 }}</ref> or the second B{{Music|flat}} above middle C (B{{Music|flat}}<sub>5</sub>).<ref name=McKinney /> The contralto voice type is generally divided into the coloratura, lyric, and dramatic contralto.
== History == "Contralto" is primarily meaningful only in reference to classical and [[opera]]tic singing, as other traditions lack a comparable [[Voice classification in non-classical music|system of vocal categorization]]. The term "contralto" is only applied to female singers; men singing in a similar range are called "[[countertenor]]s".<ref name=Appelman /> The Italian terms "contralto" and "[[alto]]" are not synonymous, the latter technically denoting a specific [[vocal range]] in choral singing without regard to factors like tessitura, vocal [[timbre]], vocal facility, and [[vocal weight]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Bel Canto: A History of Vocal Pedagogy|last=Stark|first=James|year=2003|publisher=[[University of Toronto Press]]|isbn=978-0-8020-8614-3}}</ref>
== Voice type == [[File:Contralto voice range on keyboard.svg|thumb|400px|Contralto voice range (F<sub>3</sub>–F<sub>5</sub>) notated on the [[treble clef|treble]] [[staff (music)|staff]] (left) and on piano keyboard in green with dot marking middle C (C<sub>4</sub>).]] {| align=right |<score>{ \new Staff \with { \remove "Time_signature_engraver" } f4 f''4 }</score> |} The contralto has the lowest vocal range of the female [[voice type]]s, with the lowest [[tessitura]].<ref name=Appelman>{{cite book |title= The Science of Vocal Pedagogy: Theory and Application |last= Appelman |first= D. Ralph |year= 1986 |publisher= [[Indiana University Press]] |isbn=978-0-253-20378-6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Contralto}}</ref>
The contralto voice range is between [[tenor]] and [[mezzo-soprano]]. Although tenors, baritones, and basses are male singers, some women can sing as low (albeit with a slightly different timbre and texture than their male counterparts). Unfortunately, they are often erroneously referred to as "female tenors", "female baritones", "female basses" or "androgynous." In reality, such terms are usually derogatory informal (slang). Factual formal terminology<ref>"Female Tenor...or...Profundo and Oktavistka?" Contralto Corner. 4 August 2013. {{cite web |url=http://www.contraltocorner.com/blog/female-tenor-and-female-bass-or-contralto-profondo-and-oktavistka |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-11-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920082702/http://www.contraltocorner.com/blog/female-tenor-and-female-bass-or-contralto-profondo-and-oktavistka |archivedate=2016-09-20 |df= }}</ref> would be ''contralto profundo'' (tenor) and ''contralto basso'' or ''oktavistka'' (baritone) but these are not traditionally named among the [[fach]] system.
Some of the rare contraltos that can sing the female equivalent of tenor and baritone include [[Zarah Leander]],<ref>Peucker, Brigitte. "The Material Image: Art and The Real in Film". 2007. [https://books.google.com/books?id=_B7GQLCHPVMC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120 p. 120] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905124455/https://books.google.com/books?id=_B7GQLCHPVMC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120 |date=2017-09-05 }}</ref><ref>Rosa Sala Rose. [http://rosasalarose.com/zarah_leander_and_leibstandarte_ss/ "Zarah Leander and the Leibstandarte SS".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602212734/http://rosasalarose.com/zarah_leander_and_leibstandarte_ss/ |date=2016-06-02 }} 15 December 2012. </ref> [[Ruby Helder]],<ref>[http://www.contraltocorner.com/blog/contralto-update-english-contralto-profondo-ruby-helder "Contralto Update: English Contralto Profondo Ruby Helder".] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603021637/http://www.contraltocorner.com/blog/contralto-update-english-contralto-profondo-ruby-helder |date=2016-06-03 }} Contralto Corner. 20 September 2013. </ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Elliot|first=David J.|title=Praxial Music Education: Reflections and Dialogues|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T7Og8KV3LpAC&pg=PA302&lpg=PA302&dq=ruby+helder+contralto&source=bl&ots=gDLEQOOF84&sig=eU7uEvC-0kgNM-dsmX8UCtu5FOc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_sfnS-vHSAhWK7iYKHdbMBsQQ6AEIigEwGQ#v=onepage&q=ruby%20helder%20contralto&f=false|page=302|isbn=9780199725113|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170326060551/https://books.google.com/books?id=T7Og8KV3LpAC&pg=PA302&lpg=PA302&dq=ruby+helder+contralto&source=bl&ots=gDLEQOOF84&sig=eU7uEvC-0kgNM-dsmX8UCtu5FOc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_sfnS-vHSAhWK7iYKHdbMBsQQ6AEIigEwGQ#v=onepage&q=ruby%20helder%20contralto&f=false|archivedate=2017-03-26|df=}}</ref> and [[Bally Prell]].<ref>[http://www.contraltocorner.com/blog/contralto-profondo-bally-prell-added-to-the-contralto-corner "Contralto Profondo Bally Prell Added To The Contralto Corner"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603022834/http://www.contraltocorner.com/blog/contralto-profondo-bally-prell-added-to-the-contralto-corner |date=2016-06-03 }}, Contralto Corner. 14 July 2015. </ref><ref>"Contralto Female Voice (Fach)". YouTube: DHO Gwen. 8 January 2017. {{cite web |url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=jjAwPARKYqc |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905124455/https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=jjAwPARKYqc |archivedate=2017-09-05 |df= }}</ref>
== Subtypes and roles in opera == The earliest cited role for the contralto is traditionally accepted to be that of the Saracen princess Clorinde in [[André Campra]]'s 1702 opera ''[[Tancréde]]'', and most famously performed by (and was originally written for) [[Julie d'Aubigny]].<ref name="bas-dessus">The part of Clorinde is notated in the [[soprano clef]] ([http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b9058774w/f130.image.r=Tancr%C3%A8de%201702.langEN original score, p. 71]), but, although it never descends below d′, tradition has it that it was the first major ''bas-dessus'' (contralto) role in the French opera history (Sadie, Julie Anne, ''Maupin'', in Sadie, Stanley (ed), ''op. cit.'', III, p. 274).</ref> Within the contralto voice type category are three generally recognized subcategories: [[coloratura]] contralto, lyric contralto, and dramatic contralto. These subtypes do not always apply with precision to individual singers; some exceptional dramatic contraltos, such as [[Ernestine Schumann-Heink]] and [[Sigrid Onégin]], were technically equipped to perform not only heavy, dramatic music by the likes of [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]] but also florid compositions by [[Gaetano Donizetti|Donizetti]].
=== Coloratura === The coloratura contralto has a light, agile voice ranging very high for the classification and atypically maintains extensive coloratura and high sustaining notes, specializing in florid passages and leaps. Given its deviations from the classification's norms, this voice type is quite rare.
=== Lyric=== The lyric contralto voice is lighter than a dramatic contralto but not capable of the [[Ornament (music)|ornamentation]] and leaps of a coloratura contralto. This class of contralto, lighter in timbre than the others, is the most common today and usually ranges from the E below middle C (E<sub>3</sub>) to the second G above middle C (G<sub>5</sub>).
=== Dramatic === The dramatic contralto is the deepest, darkest, and heaviest contralto voice, usually having a heavier tone and more power than the others. Singers in this class are rare.
True operatic contraltos are rare, and the operatic literature contains few roles written specifically for them. Contraltos sometimes are assigned feminine roles like Angelina in ''[[La Cenerentola]]'', Rosina in ''[[The Barber of Seville]]'', Teodata in "[[Flavio]]", Isabella in ''[[L'italiana in Algeri]]'', and Olga in ''[[Eugene Onegin (opera)|Eugene Onegin]]'', but more frequently they play female villains or [[Breeches role|trouser roles]]. Contraltos may also be cast in roles originally written for [[castrato|castrati]]. A common saying among contraltos is that they may play only "witches, bitches, or [[Wikt:britches|britches]]."<ref name=Boldrey>{{cite book |title= Guide to Operatic Roles and Arias |last= Boldrey |first= Richard |year= 1994 |publisher= Caldwell Publishing Company |isbn=978-1-877761-64-5}}</ref>
<!-- This list should be divided into the three types listed above --> Examples of contralto roles in the standard operatic repertoire include the following:<ref name=Boldrey /> {{div col|colwidth=25em|rules=yes}} *Angelina<sup>*</sup>, ''[[La Cenerentola]]'' ([[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]]) *Arsace, ''[[Semiramide]]'' (Rossini) *Art Banker, ''[[Facing Goya]]'' ([[Michael Nyman|Nyman]]) *Auntie<sup>*</sup>, landlady of The Boar, ''[[Peter Grimes]]'' ([[Benjamin Britten|Britten]]) *The Baroness, ''[[Vanessa (opera)|Vanessa]]'' ([[Samuel Barber|Barber]]) *Bradamante, ''[[Alcina]]'' ([[George Frideric Handel|Handel]]) *La Cieca, ''[[La Gioconda (opera)|La Gioconda]]'' ([[Amilcare Ponchielli|Ponchielli]]) *Cornelia ''[[Giulio Cesare]]'' (Handel) *The Countess<sup>*</sup>, ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|The Queen of Spades]]'' ([[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]]) *Didone, ''[[Egisto (opera)|Egisto]]'' ([[Francesco Cavalli|Cavalli]]) *Erda, ''[[Das Rheingold]], [[Siegfried (opera)|Siegfried]]'' ([[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]) *Madame Flora, ''[[The Medium]]'' ([[Gian Carlo Menotti|Menotti]]) *Fides, ''[[Le prophète]]'' ([[Giacomo Meyerbeer|Meyerbeer]]) *Florence, ''[[Albert Herring]]'' (Britten) *Isabella<sup>*</sup>, ''[[L'italiana in Algeri]]'' (Rossini) *Katisha, ''[[The Mikado]]'' ([[Gilbert and Sullivan]]) *Klytemnestra<sup>*</sup>, ''[[Elektra (opera)|Elektra]]'' ([[Richard Strauss]]) *Lel, ''[[The Snow Maiden]]'' ([[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov|Rimsky-Korsakov]]) *Little Buttercup, ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'' (Gilbert and Sullivan) *Lucretia, ''[[The Rape of Lucretia]]'' (Britten) *Maddalena<sup>*</sup>, ''[[Rigoletto]]'' (Verdi) *Magdelone, ''[[Maskarade]]'' ([[Carl Nielsen|Nielsen]]) *Mama Lucia, ''[[Cavalleria rusticana]]'' ([[Pietro Mascagni|Mascagni]]) *Ma Moss, ''[[The Tender Land]]'' ([[Aaron Copland|Copland]]) *Malcolm<sup>*</sup>, ''[[La donna del lago]]'' (Rossini) *Margret, ''[[Wozzeck]]'' ([[Alban Berg|Berg]]) *Maria, ''[[Porgy and Bess]]'' ([[George Gershwin|Gershwin]]) *The Marquise of Berkenfield, ''[[La fille du régiment]] ([[Gaetano Donizetti|Donizetti]]) *Marthe, ''[[Faust (opera)|Faust]]'' ([[Charles Gounod|Gounoud]]) *Mary, ''[[The Flying Dutchman (opera)|Der fliegende Holländer]]'' (Wagner) *Mother, ''[[The Consul]]'' (Menotti) *Mother Goose, ''[[The Rake's Progress]]'' ([[Igor Stravinsky|Stravinsky]]) *Mrs Quickly, ''[[Falstaff (opera)|Falstaff]]'' (Verdi) *Norn (I), ''[[Götterdämmerung]]'' (Wagner) *Olga<sup>*</sup>, ''[[Eugene Onegin (opera)|Eugene Onegin]]'' (Tchaikovsky) *Orfeo, ''[[Orfeo ed Euridice]]'' ([[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]]) *Orsini, ''[[Lucrezia Borgia (opera)|Lucrezia Borgia]]'' (Donizetti) *Pauline, ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|The Queen of Spades]]'' (Tchaikovsky) *La Principessa, ''[[Suor Angelica]]'' ([[Giacomo Puccini|Puccini]]) *Ratmir, ''[[Ruslan and Lyudmila (opera)|Ruslan and Lyudmila]]'' ([[Mikhail Glinka|Glinka]]) *Rosina<sup>*</sup>, ''[[The Barber of Seville]]'' (Rossini) *Rosmira/Eurimene<sup>*</sup>, ''[[Partenope]]'' (Handel) *Ruth, ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'' (Gilbert and Sullivan) *Schwertleite, ''[[Die Walküre]]'' (Wagner) *Smeaton, ''[[Anna Bolena]]'' (Donizetti) *Sosostris, ''[[The Midsummer Marriage]]'' ([[Michael Tippett|Tippett]]) *Stella, ''[[What Next? (opera)|What Next?]]'' ([[Elliott Carter|Carter]]) *Tancredi, ''[[Tancredi]]'' (Rossini) *Ulrica, ''[[Un ballo in maschera]]'' (Verdi) *Widow Begbick<sup>*</sup>, ''[[Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny]]'' ([[Kurt Weill|Weill]]) *3rd Woodsprite, ''[[Rusalka (opera)|Rusalka]]'' ([[Antonín Dvořák|Dvořák]]) *{{div col end}} <sup>*</sup> indicates a role that may also be sung by a [[mezzo-soprano]].
==See also== * [[:Category:Contraltos|Category of contraltos]] * [[List of operatic contraltos]] * ''[[Fach]]'', the German system for classifying voices * [[Voice classification in non-classical music]] * [[List of contraltos in non-classical music]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |title= Coloratura, Lyric and Dramatic Soprano, Vol. 1 |last= Coffin |first= Berton |year= 1960 |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc. |isbn=978-0-8108-0188-2}} * {{cite book |title= Vocal Workouts for the Contemporary Singer |last= Peckham |first= Anne |year= 2005 |publisher= Berklee Press Publications |isbn=978-0-87639-047-4}} * {{cite book |title= Choral Pedagogy |last= Smith |first= Brenda |year= 2005 |publisher= Plural Publishing, Inc |isbn=978-1-59756-043-6}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Website | name = Coolspotters | logo = Coolspotters.png | screenshot = | caption = Screenshot of Coolspotters.com as of March 2009 | url = [http://coolspotters.com http://coolspotters.com] | alexa = 20,688<ref>[http://www.alexa.com/data/details/main/coolspotters.com Alexa.com]. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> | commercial = Yes | type = [[Social Networking]], [[Celebrity]], [[Shopping]] | language = [[English language|English]] | owner = [[Fanzter|Fanzter Inc.]] | creators = Aaron LaBerge & Eric Kirsten | launch date = May, 2008 }} '''Coolspotters''' is a website focused on the fashion, products, and brands used by celebrities and trendsetters, and seen in movies and television. Founded by Aaron LaBerge and Eric Kirsten, the site launched in public beta on May 7, 2008 by [[Fanzter|Fanzter Inc.]]<ref>[http://fanzter.com/blog/2008/05/07/coolspotters-launches-to-the-world/ Fanzter, Inc. blog] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104090346/http://fanzter.com/blog/2008/05/07/coolspotters-launches-to-the-world/ |date=2010-01-04 }}. Retrieved March 12, 2009.</ref>
The website has been owned and operated by Website Brands, Inc. since October, 2014.
==Features== The features of Coolspotters are primarily focused on creating connections between celebrities, products, brands, and entertainment (TV and movies).<ref>[http://coolspotters.com/tour Coolspotters.com Tour]. Retrieved March 14, 2009.</ref> Information is entered onto the site by its users.
==Awards== * Coolspotters was listed as one of the top 100 websites of 2009 by [[PC Magazine]] and won an [[Open Web Award]] for best fashion application (won both Blogger and People's Choice), 2009.<ref>[http://mashable.com/2008/12/16/open-web-awards-2-winners/ Mashable Open Web Awards]. Retrieved March 12, 2009.</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.Coolspotters.com/ Coolspotters.com]
[[Category:Fashion websites]] [[Category:Entertainment websites]]

{{Infobox card game | title = Deer in the Headlights | subtitle =Card Game | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | alt_name = | named_variant = <!-- names of variant games that are listed on this page (rules must be different, even if only slightly) --> | designer =Front Porch Classics | publisher =University Games | date = | type = | family = | players =2+ | ages =8+ | num_cards = | deck = | play = | card_rank =2 - 10 | origin = | related = | playing_time = | random_chance = | skills =Math | website = | footnotes = }}
The Front Porch Classics game Deer in the Headlights is a card game involving two or more players aged eight and up. <ref name=":0">{{cite web|url= https://www.universitygames.com/deerintheheadlights|title= Deer in the Headlights Card Game|author= University Games|date= |work= |publisher= University Games|accessdate= }}</ref> The object of the game is to be the first player to discard their hand of cards in each round to tally the least points and win the game.
The game is part of the University Game Corporation as of 2014 and can be found in many mainline department stores. <ref name=":1">{{cite web|url= https://www.amazon.com/Front-Porch-Classics-53720-Headlights/dp/B008EBLMS6|title= Deer in the Headlights|author= Amazon|date= |work= |publisher= Front Porch Classics|accessdate= }}</ref>
==Setup==
Each game comes with two decks of custom cards, three wooden die, scorecards, and an instruction manual. <ref name=":1" />
All 3 die will be used in a game. Each dice includes a mix of standard numbers and specialized characters. The characters account for “special rolls” and are shown as a car, a running deer, or a deer in headlights. <ref name=":0" />
The number of the decks dealt out is up to the players. For instance, two players may choose to only deal out one deck. All of the cards in a deck must be dealt out; dealing out two decks of cards will result in a longer game depending on the number of players involved.
Jokers are discarded from the deck. Space must be made in the center of the playing space for the discarded cards to be placed, and then the play may begin.
==Gameplay==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Deer in the Headlights game materials.png|thumb|left|Game pieces included with Deer in the Headlights]] -->
The object of the game is to be the first player to discard all of the cards in their hand to end the round. Once a round has finished, the rest of the players count their scores by adding up the total value of the remaining cards in their hand. Each player’s score is recorded on the scorecard; the score of the round is recorded in the upper box and the cumulative score is tallied in the lower box. <ref name=":0" />
The game is concluded with the first player to reach 150 points – this player loses the game. The winner of the game is the player who has tallied the least points by the game’s end. <ref name=":0" />
All cards are added by their associated value. Aces are worth one point. Jacks, Queens, and Kings are all worth ten points each. <ref name=":0" />
Players take turns tossing the die, starting with the dealer. Each player conducts their turn based on the card play associated with their roll. There are ten different variations of card plays available. <ref name=":0" />
===Card Plays=== <ref>{{cite book |last = n/a |first = Front Porch Classics |authorlink = n/a |title = Deer in the Headlights Instruction Manual |publisher = University Games |series = |year = 2018 |doi = |isbn = }}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Dice Roll !! Associated Card Play !! Where to Discard |- | 3 Numbers || All cards corresponding to numbers rolled If rolling player cannot play, then non-rolling players may transfer their associated cards to rolling player || Center Pile |- | 2 Numbers + 1 Deer in headlights || All cards from only one of the two numbers rolled || Centre Pile |- | 2 Numbers + 1 Car || All cards that correspond to numbers rolled || Pass to any other player(s) |- | 2 Numbers + 1 Running deer || All cards from numbers rolled plus all of any other card from hand || Centre Pile |- | 1 Number + 1 Deer in headlights + 1 Car || All cards matching the number rolled plus any cards which add up to the number rolled || Pass to any other player(s) |- | 1 Number + 1 Deer in headlights + 1 Running deer || All odd or even cards based on the value of the number dice rolled || Centre Pile |- | 2 Deer in headlights + 1 Number || Lose a turn || |- | 2 Deer in headlights + 1 Car || Assign “Lose Your Turn” to any other player and roll again || |- | 2 Deer in headlights + 1 Running deer || All of any two cards from their hand || Center Pile |- | 3 Deer in headlights || Rolling player is frozen and picks up all cards in the center pile. On their next roll, they must roll a “Deer in headlights” to re-enter the game, and will play that turn according to the dice rolled || |}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox video game | title = Demons’ Score | collapsible = | state = | image = Demons Score logo iNiS Square Enix.png | caption = | developer = [[iNiS]] | publisher = [[Square Enix]] | series = | engine = [[Unreal Engine 3]] | platforms = [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] | released = 19 September 2012 | genre = [[Rhythm game|Rhythm]] | modes = | director = {{ubl|Hidehito Tanba|[[Yoko Taro]]{{cite web|url=http://www.gamebusiness.jp/article.php?id=9439|title=【GDC 2014】ヨコオタロウ氏が語るゲームシナリオの書き方。変わった人のための変わったゲーム|author=|publisher=GameBusiness.jp|date=2014-03-27|accessdate=2015-06-22|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427093601/http://www.gamebusiness.jp/article.php?id=9439|archivedate=2015-04-27|deadurl=no}}}} | producer = [[Takashi Tokita]] | designer = | programmer = | artist = {{ubl|Akira Oguro|Jiro Tomioka}} | writer = Hidehito Tanba | composer = {{collapsible list|title=List of composers|1=[[Naoshi Mizuta]]
Keiichi Okabe
[[Hiroki Kikuta]]
[[Yoko Shimomura]]
Takamichi Yashiki
Hirokazu Koshio
Shohei Tsuchiya
[[Kenichi Maeyamada]]
[[Kenji Ito]]
Koehi Tanaka
[[Hidenori Iwasaki]]
[[Ryo Yamazaki]]}} }} '''''Demons' Score''''' is a [[rhythm game|rhythm]] [[mobile game]] developed by [[iNiS]] and published by [[Square Enix]]. The gameplay is similar to another iNiS-developed game, ''[[Elite Beat Agents]]''.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5944715/the-most-diabolical-aspect-of-squares-demons-score-is-the-hellish-hidden-cost |title=The Most Diabolical Aspect of Square's Demons' Score is the Hellish Hidden Cost |publisher=Kotaku.com |date=2012-09-19 |accessdate=2012-10-02}} The game was released for [[iOS]] in September 2012, and for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] two months later.{{cite web|url=http://www.eirgames.com/1096/demons-score-nuovo-rhythm-game-smartphone-square-enix/ |title=Demon's Score available on iOS and Android |publisher=EIR Games |date=2012-11-28|author = Mauro Piccillo}} The game was disconnected in September 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.square-enix.co.jp/smart/demons/en/#!/top |title=DEMONS' SCORE |access-date=2014-12-13}} ==Story== Serenity is just an average college girl, but when she suddenly loses contact with her father Dr. Aleister, she sets out to find him at the Salem State Hospital & Asylum where he works. Serenity arrives to find she barely recognizes the hospital any more. Stepping warily into the shattered ruins, she meets a talking teddy bear. Introducing himself as David, the talking teddy bear claims to have once been human, but when Serenity asks him about her father’s whereabouts, countless demons suddenly appear. Just before her father disappeared, he had sent a mysterious app to her smartphone. Known as the Demons' Score, the app is a powerful program that enables her to take control of demons that possess her body.https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/demons-score/id532473429?mt=8 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.square-enix.co.jp/smart/demons/en/#!/top}} [[Category:2012 video games]] [[Category:Products and services discontinued in 2014]] [[Category:Action video games]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:Dark fantasy video games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Square Enix games]] [[Category:Music video games]] [[Category:Unreal Engine games]] [[Category:Video games scored by Kenji Ito]] [[Category:Video games scored by Yoko Shimomura]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games featuring female protagonists]] [[Category:Inactive online games]] {{SquareEnix-stub}}

[[File:Dieter nuhr 20061211.jpg|thumb|The current host of the ceremony, [[Dieter Nuhr]] (2006)]] The '''German Comedy Award''' is a television award and one of the most prestigious awards for [[Germany|German]] television [[comedy]].
The awards ceremony takes place annually in [[Cologne]].
== Award winners == A list of all nominees and award winners since the beginning of the ceremony in 1997:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myspass.de/myspass/specials/der-deutsche-comedypreis/preistraeger.php |title= Alle Gewinner seit 1997 im Überblick |trans-title=All winner since 1997 in an overview |work=myspass.de |accessdate=29 December 2013| language=German}}</ref>
=== German Comedy Award 1997 === *''German Comedy Award'': ** [[Renate Berger]] and [[Thomas Hermanns]] (for ''[[Quatsch Comedy Club]]'')
=== German Comedy Award 1998 === *''Best Comedyact'': [[Oliver Kalkofe]] (for ''[[Kalkofes Mattscheibe]]'') *''Best Comedyact - Newcomer'': [[Marcus Jeroch]] *''Best Basis comedy'': ''[[Titanic (magazine)|Titanic]]''
=== German Comedy Award 1999 === <small> 17 December 1999; presented by [[Theo West]]</small>
*''Best Comedian, male'': [[Michael Mittermeier]] *''Best Comedian, female'': [[Gaby Köster]] (for ''[[Ritas Welt]]'') *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Lukas (TV series)|Lukas]]'' *''Best Comedy show'': ''[[Die Wochenshow]]'' *''Best Moderation'': [[Stefan Raab]] (for ''[[TV total]]'') *''Best Music comedy'': [[Ö La Palöma Boys]] *''Best Humorous commercial'': [[RWE Dea|DEA]]-spot ''„Super Ingo!“'' *''Best Radio comedy'': [[Elmar Brandt]] and [[Peter Burtz]] (for ''[[Die Gerd-Show]]'') *''Honorary award'': [[Karl Dall]]
=== German Comedy Award 2000 === <small>12 December 2000; presented by [[Theo West]] and [[Atze Schröder]]</small>
*''Best Comedy act'': [[Atze Schröder]] (for ''[[Alles Atze]]'') *''Best Music comedy'': [[Helge Schneider]] *''Best Comedian male/female in a supporting role'': [[Franziska Traub]] (for ''[[Ritas Welt]]'') *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Ritas Welt]]'' *''Best Comedy show'': ''[[Quatsch Comedy Club]]'' *''Best Newcomer'': [[Alf Poier]] *''Best Humorous commercial'': [[Verona Feldbusch]] *''Special award for unintentional comedy'': ''[[Tagesschau (Germany)|Tagesschau]]'' *''Honorary award'': [[Jochen Busse]] *''Best Comedian, male (audience award)'': [[Michael Mittermeier]] *''Best Comedian, female (audience award)'': [[Anke Engelke]] (for ''[[Anke (TV series)|Anke]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Mariele Millowitsch]] (for ''[[Nikola (TV series)|Nikola]]''), [[Gaby Köster]] (for ''[[Ritas Welt]]'')</small>
=== German Comedy Award 2001 === <small>2.November 2001; presented by [[Gaby Köster]]</small>
*''Best Comedian, male'': [[Michael Bully Herbig]] (for ''[[Bullyparade]]'') ::<small>nominations: [[Kaya Yanar]] (for ''[[Was guckst du?!]]''), [[Michael Mittermeier]]</small> *''Best Comedian, female'': [[Anke Engelke]] (for ''[[Anke]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Cordula Stratmann]] (for ''[[Zimmer frei!]]''), [[Annette Frier]] (for ''[[Die Wochenshow]]'')</small> *''Best Comedy show'': ''[[Was guckst du?!]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Freitag Nacht News]]'', ''[[TV Total]]''</small> *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Ritas Welt]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Alles Atze]]'', ''[[Anke (TV series)|Anke]]''</small> *''Best Comedy film'': ''[[Der Schuh des Manitu]]'' *''Best Humorous commercial'': ([[Audi]])-Spot ''„Der Elvis-Fan“'' ::<small> nominations: [[Apollo-Optik]], [[Media Markt]]</small> *''Best Newcomer'': [[Johann König (comedian)|Johann König]] *''Honorary award'': [[Rudi Carrell]]
=== German Comedy Award 2002 === <small>19 October 2002; presented by [[Gaby Köster]] and [[Atze Schröder]]</small>
*''Best Comedy show'': ''[[Ladykracher]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Bullyparade]]'', ''[[Krüger sieht alles]]''</small> *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Hausmeister Krause – Ordnung muss sein]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Die Camper]]'', ''[[Mein Leben & Ich]]''</small> *''Best Comedian male/female in supporting role'': [[Christoph Maria Herbst]] (for ''[[Ladykracher]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Dana Golombek]] (for ''[[Die Camper]]''), [[Bettina Zimmermann]] (for ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Erkan & Stefan gegen die Mächte der Finsternis|de}}'')</small> *''Best Comedian, male'': [[Markus Maria Profitlich]] (for ''[[Mensch Markus]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Bernd Stelter]] (for ''[[Bernds Hexe]]''), [[Tom Gerhardt]] (for ''[[Hausmeister Krause – Ordnung muss sein]]'')</small> *''Best Comedian, female'': [[Anke Engelke]] (for ''[[Ladykracher]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Cordula Stratmann]] (for ''[[Annemie Hülchrath - Der Talk]]''), [[Mariele Millowitsch]] (for ''[[Nikola (TV series)|Nikola]]'')</small> *''Best Newcomer'': [[Axel Stein]] (for ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Feuer, Eis & Dosenbier|de}}'', ''[[Hausmeister Krause - Ordnung muss sein]]'' and ''[[Knallharte Jungs]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Felicitas Woll]] (for ''[[Berlin, Berlin]]''), [[Elton (comedian)|Elton]] (for ''[[Elton.tv]]'')</small> *''Best Live comedy'': [[Michael Mittermeier]] (for ''Back to life'') *''Best Comedy film'': ''[[Knallharte Jungs]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Erkan & Stefan gegen die Mächte der Finsternis|de}}'', ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Feuer, Eis & Dosenbier|de}}''</small> *''Honorary Award'': [[Otto Waalkes]]
=== German Comedy Award 2003 === <small> 11. October 2003; presented by [[Atze Schröder]]</small>
*''Best Comedian male/female'': [[Bastian Pastewka]] (for ''[[Ohne Worte]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Anke Engelke]] (for ''[[Ladykracher]]''), [[Kaya Yanar]] (for ''[[Was guckst du?!]]'')</small> *''Best Comedy show'': ''[[Genial daneben – Die Comedy Arena]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[OLM!]]'', ''[[TV Total]]''</small> *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Alles Atze]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Bewegte Männer]]'', ''[[Nikola (TV series)|Nikola]]''</small> *''Best Actor in a television comedy'': [[Atze Schröder]] (for ''[[Alles Atze]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Axel Stein]] (for ''[[Axel!]]''), [[Willi Thomczyk]] (for ''[[Die Camper]]'')</small> *''Best Actress in a television comedy'': [[Gaby Köster]] (for ''[[Ritas Welt]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Heike Kloss]] (for ''[[Alles Atze]]''), [[Julia Stinshoff]] (for ''[[Crazy Race]]'')</small> *''Best Sketch show'': ''[[Ladykracher]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Alt und durchgeknallt]]'', ''[[Ohne Worte]]''</small> *''Best Newcomer'': [[Ralf Schmitz]] (for ''[[Die dreisten Drei]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Johnny Challah]] (for ''[[Axel!]]''), [[Mirja Boes]] (for ''[[Die dreisten Drei]]'')</small> *''Best Live act'': [[Dieter Nuhr]] *''TV Special award'': [[Anke Engelke]] *''Honorary award'': [[Dieter Hallervorden]] *''Special award for First successful German television comedy-show'': ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Klimbim|de}}''
=== German Comedy Award 2004 === <small> 17 October 2004; presented by [[Atze Schröder]]</small>
*''Best Comedian male/female'': [[Michael Bully Herbig]] (for ''[[(T)Raumschiff Surprise - Periode 1]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Atze Schröder]], [[Bastian Pastewka]], [[Hans Werner Olm]]</small> *''Best Comedy show'': ''[[OLM!]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Zimmer frei!]]'', ''[[Rent a Pocher]]''</small> *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Familie Heinz Becker]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Mein Leben & Ich]]'', ''[[Was nicht passt, wird passend gemacht (TV series)|Was nicht passt, wird passend gemacht]]''</small> *''Best Actor in a television comedy'': [[Ingo Naujoks]] (for ''[[Bewegte Männer]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Walter Sittler]] (for ''[[Nikola (TV series)|Nikola]]''), [[Ralf Richter (actor)|Ralf Richter]] (for ''[[Was nicht passt, wird passend gemacht (TV series)|Was nicht passt, wird passend gemacht]]'')</small> *''Best Actress in a television comedy'': [[Wolke Hegenbarth]] (for ''[[Mein Leben & Ich]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Janine Kunze]] (for ''[[Hausmeister Krause – Ordnung muss sein]]''), [[Arzu Bazman]] (for ''[[Schulmädchen]]'')</small> *''Best Moderation'': [[Hape Kerkeling]] (for ''[[Die 70er Show]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Sonja Zietlow]] and [[Dirk Bach]] (for ''[[Ich bin ein Star – Holt mich hier raus!]]''), [[Oliver Pocher]] and [[Kai Pflaume]] (for ''[[Wok-WM]]'')</small> *''Best Sketch show'': ''[[Mensch Markus]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Die dreisten Drei]]'', ''[[Tramitz and Friends]]''</small> *''Best Newcomer'': [[Hennes Bender]] ::<small> nominations: [[Ingo Oschmann]], [[Mario Barth]]</small> *''Best Live comedy'': [[Michael Mittermeier]] *''Best Comedy film'': ''[[(T)Raumschiff Surprise - Periode 1]]'' *''Honorary award'': [[Emil Steinberger (actor)|Emil Steinberger]] *''Special award'': ''[[7 Tage, 7 Köpfe]]''
=== German Comedy Award 2005 === <small> 15 October 2005; presented by [[Atze Schröder]]</small>
*''Best Comedy show'': ''[[Rent a Pocher]]'' ::<small>nominations: ''[[Hape trifft!]]'', ''[[Freitag Nacht News]]'', ''[[Kalkofes Mattscheibe]]'' </small> *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Alles Atze]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Stromberg (TV series)|Stromberg]]'', ''[[Axel! will’s wissen]]'', ''[[Mein Leben & Ich]]''</small> *''Best Actor/Actress in a television comedy'': [[Christoph Maria Herbst]] (for ''[[Stromberg (TV series)|Stromberg]]'') ::<small> nominations: [[Wolke Hegenbarth]], [[Sabine Pfeifer]], [[Rick Kavanian]]</small> *''Best Sketch show'': ''[[Bully & Rick]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Ohne Worte]]'', ''[[Die dreisten Drei]]'', ''[[Tramitz and Friends]]''</small> *''Best Comedian, male'': [[Hape Kerkeling]] ::<small> nominations: [[Bully Herbig]], [[Ralf Schmitz]], [[Oliver Pocher]]</small> *''Best Comedian, female'': [[Cordula Stratmann]] ::<small> nominations: [[Mirja Boes]], [[Hella von Sinnen]], [[Gaby Köster]]</small> *''Best Improvisational comedy, TV'': ''[[Schillerstraße (TV series)|Schillerstraße]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Frei Schnauze]]'', ''[[Dittsche]]'', ''[[Genial daneben]]''</small> *''Best Comedy film'': ''[[7 Zwerge – Männer allein im Wald]]'' *''Best Newcomer'': [[Kurt Krömer]] *''Best Live comedy'': [[Mario Barth]] *''Honorary award'': [[Helge Schneider]]
=== German Comedy Award 2006 === <small>10 October 2006; presented by [[Atze Schröder]]</small>
*''Best Comedy show'': ''[[Genial daneben|Genial daneben – Die Comedy Arena]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Hape trifft!]]'', ''[[Schmitz komm raus!]]''</small> *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Pastewka (TV series)|Pastewka]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Stromberg (TV series)|Stromberg]]'', ''[[Mein Leben & Ich]]''</small> *''Best Sketch comedy'': ''[[Mensch Markus]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Die dreisten Drei]]'', ''[[Sechserpack]]''</small> *''Best Comedy film'': ''[[Ladyland]]'' ::<small> nominations: ''[[Arme Millionäre]]'', ''[[Die ProSieben Märchenstunde]]''</small> *''Best Comedian, male'': [[Hape Kerkeling]] ::<small> nominations: [[Oliver Pocher]], [[Ralf Schmitz]]</small> *''Best Comedian, female'': [[Hella von Sinnen]] ::<small> nominations: [[Cordula Stratmann]], [[Mirja Boes]]</small> *''Best Actor'': [[Christoph Maria Herbst]] ::<small> nominations: [[Bastian Pastewka]], [[Sky du Mont]]</small> *''Best Actress'': [[Andrea Sawatzki]] ::<small> nominations: [[Anke Engelke]], [[Wolke Hegenbarth]]</small> *''Best Live comedy'': [[Mario Barth]] *''Best Newcomer'': [[Dieter Tappert|Paul Panzer]] *''Best Comedian, international'': Borat (alias [[Sacha Baron Cohen]]) *''Special award'': Horst Schlämmer (alias [[Hape Kerkeling]]) *''Honorary Award'': [[Jürgen von der Lippe]]

*''Best Sketch show'': ''[[Switch reloaded]]'' ::<small>nominations: ''[[Bully & Rick]]'', ''[[Kargar trifft den Nagel]]''</small> *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Kinder, Kinder]]'' ::<small>nominations: ''[[Türkisch für Anfänger]]'', ''[[Pastewka (TV series)|Pastewka]]''</small> *''Beste Comedy show'': ''[[Frei Schnauze XXL]]'' ::<small>nominations: ''[[Extreme Activity]]'', ''[[Dieter Tappert|Paul Panzers 33]]''</small> *''Best Actor in a television comedy'': [[Christoph Maria Herbst]] ::<small>nominations: [[Christian Ulmen]], [[Heinrich Schafmeister]]</small> *''Best Actress in a television comedy'': [[Anke Engelke]] ::<small>nominations: [[Carolin Kebekus]], [[Josefine Preuß]]</small> *''Best Newcomer'': [[Ilka Bessin|Cindy aus Marzahn]] ::<small>nominations: [[Heinz Gröning|Der unglaubliche Heinz]], Stefan Schramm & Christoph Walther</small> *''Best Comedian, male'': [[Hape Kerkeling]] ::<small>nominations: [[Oliver Pocher]], [[Mario Barth]]</small> *''Best Comedian, female'': [[Gaby Köster]] ::<small>nominations: [[Mirja Boes]], [[Cordula Stratmann]]</small> *''Best Comedy film'': ''[[7 Zwerge - Der Wald ist nicht genug]]'' *''Best Live comedy'': [[Mario Barth]] *''Honorary award'': [[Vicco von Bülow|Loriot]]
=== German Comedy Award 2008 === <small>21 October 2008; presented by [[Dieter Nuhr]]</small> *''Best Television comedy'': ''[[Doctor's Diary]]'' ::<small>nominations: ''[[Maddin in Love]]'', ''[[Herzog (TV series)|Herzog]]'', ''[[Two Funny]]''</small> *''Best Comedy show'': ''[[Elton vs. Simon|Elton vs. Simon - Die Show]]'' ::<small>nominations: ''[[Achtung! Hartwich]]'', ''[[Kurt Krömer|Krömer - Die Internationale Show]]''</small> *''Best Comedy event'': ''[[Fröhliche Weihnachten! - mit Wolfgang & Anneliese]]'' ::<small>nominations: ''[[Michael Mittermeier|20 Jahre Mittermeier]]'', ''[[Otto Waalkes|Happy Otto - Wir haben Grund zum Feiern]]''</small> *''Best Sketch comedy'': ''[[Switch reloaded]]'' ::<small>nominations: ''Wunderbar'', ''[[Two Funny]]''</small> *''Best Actor': [[Michael Kessler]] ::<small>nominations: [[Christian Ulmen]], [[Dirk Bach]]</small> *''Best Actress'': [[Nora Tschirner]] ::<small>nominations: [[Judith Richter]], [[Susan Sideropoulos]]</small> *''Best Newcomer'': [[Olaf Schubert]] *''Best Comedian, male'': [[Michael Mittermeier]] ::<small>nominations: [[Oliver Pocher]], [[Mario Barth]]</small> *''Best Comedian, female'': [[Mirja Boes]] ::<small>nominations: [[Anke Engelke]], [[Ilka Bessin|Cindy aus Marzahn]]</small> *''Best German comedy film'': ''[[Keinohrhasen]]'' *''Best Live comedy'': [[Mario Barth]] *''Honorary award'': [[Hugo Egon Balder]]
=== German Comedy Award 2009 === <small>20 October 2009; presented by [[Dieter Nuhr]]</small>

{{multiple issues| {{Technical|date=April 2012}} {{no footnotes|date=December 2009}} }} [[File:Altmer High Elves trapped and outnumbered but we won't die today.jpg|thumb|Four images assembled into one final image]] '''Digital compositing''' is the process of digitally assembling multiple images to make a final image, typically for print, [[film|motion pictures]] or screen display. It is the digital analogue of optical film [[compositing]].
==Mathematics== The basic operation used in digital compositing is known as '[[alpha compositing#Alpha blending|alpha blending]]', where an opacity value, 'α', is used to control the proportions of two input [[pixel]] values that end up a single output pixel.
As a simple example, suppose two images of the same size are available and they are to be composited. The input images are referred to as the foreground image and the background image. Each image consists of the same number of [[pixel]]s. Compositing is performed by mathematically combining information from the corresponding pixels from the two input images and recording the result in a third image, which is called the composited image.
Consider three pixels; * a foreground pixel, f * a background pixel, b * a composited pixel, c and * α, the opacity value of the foreground pixel. (α = 1 for opaque foreground, α = 0 for a completely transparent foreground). A monochrome raster image where the pixel values are to be interpreted as alpha values is known as a [[matte (filmmaking)|matte]].
Then, considering all three colour channels, and assuming that the colour channels are expressed in a γ=1 colour space (that is to say, the measured values are proportional to light intensity), we have:
:c<sub>r</sub> = α f<sub>r</sub> + (1 − α) b<sub>r</sub> :c<sub>g</sub> = α f<sub>g</sub> + (1 − α) b<sub>g</sub> :c<sub>b</sub> = α f<sub>b</sub> + (1 − α) b<sub>b</sub>
Note that if the operations are performed in a colour space where γ is not equal to 1 then the operation will lead to non-linear effects which can potentially be seen as [[aliasing]] artifacts (or '[[jaggies]]') along sharp edges in the matte. More generally, nonlinear compositing can have effects such as "halos" around composited objects, because the influence of the alpha channel is non-linear. It is possible for a compositing artist to compensate for the effects of compositing in non-linear space.
Performing alpha blending is an expensive operation if performed on an entire image or 3D scene. If this operation has to be done in real time video games there is an easy trick to boost performance.
:c<sub>out</sub> = α f<sub>in</sub> + (1 − α) b<sub>in</sub> :c<sub>out</sub> = α f<sub>in</sub> + b<sub>in</sub> − α b<sub>in</sub> :c<sub>out</sub> = b<sub>in</sub> + α (f<sub>in</sub> − b<sub>in</sub>)
By simply rewriting the mathematical expression one can save 50% of the multiplications required.
===Algebraic properties=== When many partially transparent layers need to be composited together, it is worthwhile to consider the algebraic properties of compositing operators used. Specifically, the associativity and commutativity determine when repeated calculation can or cannot be avoided.
Consider the case when we have four layers to blend to produce the final image: F=A*(B*(C*D)) where A, B, C, D are partially transparent image layers and "*" denotes a compositing operator (with the left layer on top of the right layer). If only layer C changes, we should find a way to avoid re-blending all of the layers when computing F. Without any special considerations, four full-image blends would need to occur. For compositing operators that are [[commutative]], such as [[additive blending]], it is safe to re-order the blending operations. In this case, we might compute T=A*(B*D) only once and simply blend T*C to produce F, a single operation. Unfortunately, most operators are not commutative. However, many are [[associative]], suggesting it is safe to re-group operations to F=(A*B)*(C*D), i.e. without changing their order. In this case we may compute S:=A*B once and save this result. To form F with an associative operator, we need only do two additional compositing operations to integrate the new layer S, by computing F:=S*(C*D). Note that this expression indicates compositing C with all of the layers below it in one step and then blending all of the layers on top of it with the previous result to produce the final image in the second step.
If all layers of an image change regularly but a large number of layer still need to be composited (such as in distributed rendering), the commutativity of a compositing operator can still be exploited to speed up computation through [[parallelism (computing)|parallelism]] even when there is no gain from pre-computation. Again, consider the image F=A*(B*(C*D)). Each compositing operation in this expression depends on the next, leading to serial computation. However, associativity can allow us to rewrite F=(A*B)*(C*D) where there are clearly two operations that do not depend on each other that may be executed in parallel. In general, we can build a tree of pair-wise compositing operations with a height that is logarithmic in the number of layers.
==Software ==
The most historically significant nonlinear compositing system was the [[Cineon]], which operated in a logarithmic color space, which more closely mimics the natural light response of film emulsions (the Cineon system, made by Kodak, is no longer in production). Due to the limitations of processing speed and memory, compositing artists did not usually have the luxury of having the system make intermediate conversions to linear space for the compositing steps. Over time, the limitations have become much less significant, and now most compositing is done in a linear color space, even in cases where the source imagery is in a logarithmic color space.
Compositing often also includes scaling, retouching and colour correction of images.
===Node-based and layer-based compositing=== There are two radically different digital compositing workflows: node-based compositing and layer-based compositing.
Node-based compositing represents an entire composite as a tree graph, linking media objects and effects in a procedural map, intuitively laying out the progression from source input to final output, and is in fact the way all compositing applications internally handle composites. This type of compositing interface allows great flexibility, including the ability to modify the parameters of an earlier image processing step "in context" (while viewing the final [[compositing|composite]]). Node-based compositing packages often handle keyframing and time effects poorly, as their workflow does not stem directly from a timeline, as do layer-based compositing packages. Software which incorporates a node based interface include [[Natron (software)|Natron]], [[Apple Shake]], [[Blender (software)|Blender]], [[Blackmagic Fusion]], and [[Nuke (software)|The Foundry's Nuke]].
Layer-based compositing represents each media object in a composite as a separate layer within a timeline, each with its own time bounds, effects, and keyframes. All the layers are stacked, one above the next, in any desired order; and the bottom layer is usually [[rendering (computer graphics)|rendered]] as a base in the resultant image, with each higher layer being progressively rendered on top of the previously composited of layers, moving upward until all layers have been rendered into the final composite. Layer-based compositing is very well suited for rapid [[2D computer graphics|2D]] and limited [[3D computer graphics|3D]] effects such as in motion graphics, but becomes awkward for more complex composites entailing a large number of layers. A partial solution to this is some programs' ability to view the composite-order of elements (such as images, effects, or other attributes) with a visual diagram called a [[Flowchart (Adobe)|flowchart]] to nest compositions, or "comps," directly into other compositions, thereby adding complexity to the render-order by first compositing layers in the beginning composition, then combining that resultant image with the layered images from the proceeding composition, and so on. An example of this exists in the Adobe program [[After Effects]].
== See also == * [[Broadcast designer]] * [[Chroma key]] * [[Digital asset]] * [[Digital cinema]] * [[Digital on-screen graphic]] (BUG) * [[Gamma correction]] * [[Graphics coordinator]] * [[Motion graphic]] * [[Motion graphic design]]
==Further reading== * {{cite conference |author1=Mansi Sharma |author2=Santanu Chaudhury |author3=Brejesh Lall |author4= | conference=Proceedings of the 2014 Indian Conference on Computer Vision Graphics and Image Processing, ACM New York, NY, USA | title=Content-aware seamless stereoscopic 3D compositing | date=2014 | doi=10.1145/2683483.2683555 | url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2683555 }} * [[Tom Porter (computer scientist)|T. Porter]] and [[Tom Duff|T. Duff]], "Compositing Digital Images", Proceedings of [[SIGGRAPH]] '84, 18 (1984). * The Art and Science of Digital Compositing ({{ISBN|0-12-133960-2}})

revision.text:
[[File:Expandable Water Toy.jpeg|thumb|The "Grow A Boyfriend" expandable water toy shown at its original size]] '''Expandable water toys''' or '''Grow-in-water toys''', often called '''Grow Monsters''' are [[novelty item]]s made from a [[superabsorbent polymer]]. They are toys that expand after putting them into water for several days. Also, it shrinks with saltwater, though most shrink simply from air after being removed from water. They are made from polymers that can absorb and retain extremely large amounts of a liquid relative to their own mass.<ref>http://www.iupac.org/publications/pac/2004/pdf/7604x0889.pdf</ref>
==Description== Grow Monsters come in many different shapes and sizes. [[Reptiles]] and dinosaurs are common figures, but there are many others, such as: sharks, squid, seahorses, lobster, insects, humans, and mechas from popular [[anime]] are among them. Many of the companies that distribute them are Chinese trading companies.<ref>http://www.topwelltoys.com.tw/detail/8333/8333.html</ref><ref>http://www.madeinchina.com/2788469/P6032079/Novetly-Toys-Growing-Reptile-Toys-Grow-in-water-Toys-solid.shtml</ref>
Water Balz look like marbles, but expand to the size of a [[racquetball]] in water.<ref name=hazard>{{cite news|url=http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/17/expanding-ball-toy-poses-hazard-to-children-and-pets/|title=Expanding Ball Toy Poses Hazard to Children and Pets|last=O'Connor|first=Anahad|date=17 September 2012|work=Well|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref>
==History== The introduction and popularity of these toys has followed the development of superabsorbent polymers. In the early 1970s, the superabsorbent polymer was used commercially for the first time for disposable hygienic products. The first product markets were feminine sanitary napkins and adult incontinence products. The development of superabsorbent technology and performance has been largely led by demands in the disposable hygiene segment. Strides in absorption performance have allowed the development of the ultra-thin baby [[diaper]] which uses a fraction of the materials – particularly fluff pulp – that earlier disposable diapers consumed. Over the years, technology has progressed so that there is little if any starch-grafted superabsorbent polymer used in disposable hygienic products. These super absorbents typically are cross-linked acrylic homo-polymers (usually sodium neutralized).<ref>http://www.m2polymer.com/html/history_of_superabsorbents.html</ref>
==Risks and recalls== Starting from January 15, 2007 there have been several recalls on these toys. Ireland, Poland, Cyprus, Lithuania, Hungary and the United Kingdom have recalled the Magic Grow Reptile and Dinosaur Eggs Wild World due to a [[choking]] risk. They claim the products pose a risk of choking due to the fact that after 72 hours in water, the toys expand more than 500% in three directions, and that the products do not comply with the Toys Directive and the relevant European standard EN 71.<ref>http://www.toysafetyrecalls.ca</ref>
Water Balz have been swallowed and lodged in the guts of children, requiring surgery to remove.<ref name=hazard/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1970s toys]] [[Category:Water toys]] [[Category:Novelty items]] {{Toy-stub}}
