===Romances sans paroles, Op 17=== [[File:Gabriel Fauré en uniforme de l'Ecole Niedermeyer.jpg|thumb|left|upright|alt=young man in scholastic uniform of the 19th century|Fauré as a student in 1864]] Fauré wrote these three "songs without words" while still a student at the École Niedermeyer, in about 1863. They were not published until 1880, but they then became some of his most popular works. Copland considered them immature pieces, which "should be relegated to the indiscretions every young composer commits."<ref name=copland/> Later critics have taken a less severe view; Morrison describes the Romances as "an affectionate and very Gallic tribute to Mendelssohn's urbanity, agitation and ease."<ref name="m10" /> The commentator Keith Anderson writes that although they were a popular French counterpart to Mendelssohn's ''[[Songs without Words]]'', Fauré's own voice is already recognisable. Instead of placing the slowest piece in the middle of the set and ending with the lively A minor piece, Fauré, already with musical views of his own, switches the expected order, and the set ends ''pianissimo'', fading to nothing.<ref name=a4>Anderson (1993), p. 4</ref>
;Andante quasi allegretto The first romance, in A{{music|flat}} major, has as an opening theme an uncomplicated melody with Mendelssohnian syncopations. The theme is presented first in the higher and then in the middle register, before flowing evenly to its conclusion.<ref name=a4/>
;Allegro molto The second romance, in A minor, an exuberant piece, has a strong semiquaver figure supporting the theme, and running high into the treble and low into the bass. This was later to become one of Fauré's most recognisable characteristics. After a lively display, the piece ends quietly.<ref name=a4/>
;Andante moderato The final piece of the set, in A{{music|flat}} major, is a serene ''andante'', with a flowing tune in the Mendelssohnian style. After gentle variation, it equally gently fades to silence at the end.<ref name=a4/>
===Ballade in F{{music|sharp}} major, Op 19=== The Ballade, dedicated to [[Camille Saint-Saëns]], dates from 1877. It is one of Fauré's most substantial works for solo piano, but is better known in a version for piano and orchestra that he made in 1881 at Liszt's suggestion.<ref name="Nectoux" /> Playing for a little over 14 minutes, it is second in length only to the ''Thème et variations.''<ref>Morrison, pp. 3–5</ref> Fauré first conceived the music as a set of individual pieces, but then decided to make them into a single work by carrying the main theme of each section over into the following section as a secondary theme.<ref name=h7>Howat (''Piano Works by Gabriel Fauré'') p. 7</ref> The work opens with the F{{music|sharp}} major theme, an ''andante cantabile'', which is followed by a slower section, marked ''lento'', in E{{music|flat}} minor. The third section is an andante introducing a third theme. In the last section, an allegro, a return of the second theme brings the work to a conclusion in which Nectoux comments, the treble sings with particular delicacy.<ref name="Nectoux_a" />
[[Marcel Proust]] knew Fauré, and the Ballade is thought to have been the inspiration for the sonata by Proust's character Vinteuil that haunts Swann in ''[[In Search of Lost Time]]''.<ref name=h7/> [[Claude Debussy|Debussy]], reviewing an early performance of the Ballade, compared the music with the attractive soloist, straightening her shoulder-straps during the performance: "I don't know why, but I somehow associated the charm of these gestures with the music of Fauré himself. The play of fleeting curves that is its essence can be compared to the movements of a beautiful woman without either suffering from the comparison."<ref>Holloway, Robin. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1004069 "Master of Hearts",] ''The Musical Times'', Vol. 136, No. 1830 (August 1995), pp. 394–396 {{subscription}}</ref> Morrison describes the Ballade as "a reminder of halcyon, half-remembered summer days and bird-haunted forests".<ref name=m11/>
===Mazurka in B{{music|flat}} major, Op 32=== The [[Mazurka]] was composed in the mid-1870s but not published until 1883.<ref name="Nectoux_b" /> It is a tribute to Chopin, and contains echoes of the earlier composer's music.<ref name=m14/> Chopin, however, composed more than 60 mazurkas, and Fauré wrote only this one. Morrison regards it as an experiment on Fauré's part.<ref name=m14/> The piece owes little to Polish folk-dance rhythms, and may have had a Russian influence through Fauré's friendship with [[Sergei Taneyev]] at around the time of its composition.<ref>Howat (Antokoletz and Wheeldon), p. 44</ref>
===''Pavane'', Op 50=== {{main|Pavane (Fauré)}} The ''Pavane'' (1887) was conceived and originally written as an orchestral piece.<ref>Nectoux (1984), p. 130</ref> Fauré published the version for piano in 1889.<ref name=grove/><ref name=h155>Howat (2009), p. 155</ref> In the form of an ancient dance, the piece was written to be played more briskly than it has generally come to be performed in its familiar orchestral guise. The conductor [[Adrian Boult|Sir Adrian Boult]] heard Fauré play the piano version several times and noted that he took it at a tempo no slower than [[beats per minute|crochet=100]].<ref name=h272>Howat (2009), p. 272</ref> Boult commented that the composer's sprightly tempo emphasised that the ''Pavane'' was not a piece of German romanticism.<ref name=h272/>
===Thème et variations in C{{music|sharp}} minor, Op 73=== Written in 1895, when he was 50, this is among Fauré's most extended compositions for piano,<ref name=d117>Duchen (2000), p. 117</ref> with a performance time of about 15 minutes.<ref name=m3/> Although it has many passages that reflect the influence of Schumann's ''[[Symphonic Studies (Schumann)|Symphonic Studies]]'', in Jessica Duchen's words "its harmonies and pianistic idioms" are unmistakably those of Fauré.<ref name=d117/> As in the earlier ''Romances sans paroles'', Op 17, Fauré does not follow the conventional course of ending with the loudest and most extrovert variation; the variation nearest to that description is placed next to last, and is followed by a gentle conclusion, "a typically Faurean understated finish."<ref name=d117/> Copland wrote of the work: {{quote|Certainly it is one of Faure's most approachable works. Even at first hearing it leaves an indelible impression. The "Theme" itself has the same fateful, march-like tread, the same atmosphere of tragedy and heroism, that we find in the introduction of Brahms's [[Symphony No. 1 (Brahms)|First Symphony]]. And the variety and spontaneity of the eleven variations which follow bring to mind nothing less than the ''[[Symphonic Studies (Schumann)|Symphonic Etudes]].'' How many pianists, I wonder, have not regretted that the composer disdained the easy triumph of closing on the brilliant, dashing tenth variation. No, poor souls, they must turn the page and play that last, enigmatic (and most beautiful) one, which seems to leave the audience with so little desire to applaud.<ref name=copland/>|}}
===Prelude to ''Pénélope''=== Fauré's opera based on the legend of Ulysses and Penelope was first performed in 1913, after which the composer published a version of the prelude transcribed for piano. The piece, in G minor, contrasts a gravely noble ''andante moderato'' theme representing Penelope with a forthright theme for Ulysses. The polyphonic writing transfers effectively from the orchestral original to the piano.<ref name=c5/>
===''8 Pièces brèves'', Op 84=== [[File:Gabriel Fauré dans le jardin du Conservatoire.jpg|thumb|right|alt=elderly man, bowler-hatted and luxuriantly moustached in a city garden|Fauré in the gardens of the Conservatoire, 1918]] Fauré did not intend these pieces to be published as a set; they were composed as individual works between 1869 and 1902.<ref name=m4/> When [[Julien Hamelle|Hamelle]], his publishers, insisted on issuing them together as "Eight Short Pieces" in 1902, the composer successfully demanded that none of the eight must be allocated its own title. When he moved on to another publisher, Hamelle ignored his earlier instructions and issued subsequent editions with titles for each piece.{{#tag:ref|Hamelle retained the publishing rights to Fauré's earlier music after he moved to the publisher Heugel. When asked if he regretted Fauré's departure, "Père" Hamelle, head of the firm, tapped his pocket and replied, "No skin off my nose. I've got what sells."<ref>Nectoux (1991), pp. 275 (Hamelle quote) and 299 (retitling)</ref>|group= n}} Nectoux comments that the labelling of the eighth piece as "Nocturne No 8" is particularly questionable (see ''Nocturne [No 8]'', below).<ref name=n299>Nectoux (1991), p. 299</ref> In the first decade of the 21st century the publisher Peters issued a new critical edition of the Eight Pieces with the spurious titles removed.<ref name=h6>Howat (''Piano Works by Gabriel Fauré''), p. 6</ref> The eight pieces take less than three minutes each in performance.<ref name=m4>Morrison, p. 4</ref>
'''Capriccio in E{{music|flat}} major:''' Dedicated to Madame Jean Leonard Koechlin.<ref name=p133>Phillips, p. 133</ref> Morrison calls it "capricious indeed", and notes a harmonic twist at the end "as nonchalant as it is acrobatic".<ref name=m13/> It was originally written as a sight-reading test for students at the [[Paris Conservatoire]], of which Fauré was the professor of composition from 1896 and director from 1905 to 1920.<ref name=h6/>
'''Fantaisie in A{{music|flat}} major:''' Koechlin calls this piece a pleasant ''[[Album leaf (music)|feuillet d'album]]''.<ref name=k35>Koechlin, p. 35</ref>
'''Fugue in A minor:''' This, like the other fugue in the set, is a revised version of a fugue Fauré composed at the start of his career, when he was a church organist in [[Rennes]]. They are both, in Koechlin's view "in a pleasant and correct style, obviously less rich than those in the Well-Tempered Clavier, and more careful, but whose reserve conceals an incontestable mastery".<ref name=k35/>
'''Adagietto in E minor:''' An ''andante moderato'', "serious, grave, at once firm and pliant, attaining real beauty" (Koechlin).<ref name=k35/>
'''Improvisation in C{{music|sharp}} minor:''' Orledge calls this piece a middle period "song without words".<ref>Orledge, p. 97</ref> It was composed as a sight-reading test for the Conservatoire.<ref name=k35/>
'''Fugue in E minor:''' See Fugue in A minor, above.
'''Allégresse in C major:''' "A bubbling perpetuum mobile whose surging romantic feelings are only just kept under restraint" (Orledge).<ref>Orledge, pp. 97–98</ref> "A song, pure and gay, uplifted to a sunlit sky, a youthful outpouring, full of happiness." (Koechlin).<ref name=k35/>
'''Nocturne [No 8] in D{{music|flat}} major:''' As noted above, this piece stands apart from the larger-scale works to which Fauré gave the title "nocturne". It would not be listed among them were it not for the publisher's unauthorised use of the title in this case.{{#tag:ref|In at least three recorded sets of the collected piano music (Jean Philippe Collard, 1974, Paul Crossley, 1984, and Kathryn Stott, 1994) the piece is played twice – first as the last of the "Eight Short Pieces", and again as part of the set of 13 nocturnes.<ref>Morrison, pp. 4–5</ref>|group= n}} It is the longest of the eight pieces of Op 84, but is much shorter and simpler than the other 12 nocturnes, consisting of a song-like main theme with a delicate semiquaver accompaniment in the left hand.<ref name=a1/>
===9 Préludes, Op 103=== [[File:Gabriel Fauré, devant son piano, dans son appartement boulevard Malesherbes.jpg|alt=elderly man leaning against grand piano| thumb|right|300px|Fauré, next to the piano in his flat in the boulevard Malesherbes, Paris, 1905]] The nine préludes are among the least known of Fauré's major piano compositions.<ref name=oliver/> They were written while the composer was struggling to come to terms with the onset of deafness in his mid-sixties.<ref name=cochard3>Cochard, p. 3</ref> By Fauré's standards this was a time of unusually prolific output. The préludes were composed in 1909 and 1910, in the middle of the period in which he wrote the opera ''[[Pénélope]]'', barcarolles Nos. 8–11 and nocturnes Nos. 9–11.<ref name=cochard3/>
In Koechlin's view, "Apart from the ''Préludes'' of Chopin, it is hard to think of a collection of similar pieces that are so important".<ref name=k36/> The critic Michael Oliver wrote, "Fauré's Préludes are among the subtlest and most elusive piano pieces in existence; they express deep but mingled emotions, sometimes with intense directness ... more often with the utmost economy and restraint and with mysteriously complex simplicity."<ref name=oliver>Oliver, Michael. [http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/January%201988/48/756706/ "Fauré – Nine Préludes",] ''Gramophone'', January 1988, p. 48</ref> Jessica Duchen calls them "unusual slivers of magical inventiveness."<ref>Duchen (2000), p. 159</ref> The complete set takes between 20 and 25 minutes to play. The shortest of the set, No 8, lasts barely more than a minute; the longest, No 3, takes between four and five minutes.<ref>Morrison, p. 5</ref>
;Prélude No 1 in D{{music|flat}} major ''Andante molto moderato''. The first prélude is in the manner of a nocturne.<ref name=cochard3/> Morrison refers to the cool serenity with which it opens, contrasted with the "slow and painful climbing" of the middle section.<ref name=m13>Morrison, p. 13</ref>
;Prélude No 2 in C{{music|sharp}} minor ''Allegro.'' The ''moto perpetuo'' of the second prélude is technically difficult for the pianist; even the most celebrated Fauré interpreter can be stretched by it.<ref>Smith, Harriet. [http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/May%202007/101/738201/ "Fauré Franck",] ''Gramophone'', May 2007, p. 101</ref> Koechlin calls it "a feverish whirling of dervishes, concluding in a sort of ecstasy, with the evocation of some fairy palace."<ref name=k35/>
;Prélude No 3 in G minor ''Andante.'' Copland considered this prélude the most immediately accessible of the set. "At first, what will most attract you, will be the third in G-minor, a strange mixture of the romantic and classic."<ref name=copland/> The musicologist [[Vladimir Jankélévitch]] wrote, "it might be a barcarolle strangely interrupting a theme of very modern stylistic contour".<ref name=jank>''Quoted'' in Cochard, p. 3</ref>
;Prélude No 4 in F major ''Allegretto moderato.'' The fourth prélude is among the gentlest of the set. The critic Alain Cochard writes that it "casts a spell on the ear through the subtlety of a harmony tinged with the modal and its melodic freshness."<ref name=cochard4>Cochard, p. 4</ref> Koechlin calls it "a guileless pastorale, flexible, with succinct and refined modulations".<ref name=k35/>
;Prélude No 5 in D minor ''Allegro.'' Cochard quotes the earlier writer [[Louis Aguettant]]'s description of this prélude as "This fine outburst of anger (''Ce bel accès de colère'')". The mood is turbulent and anxious;<ref name=cochard4/> the piece ends in quiet resignation reminiscent of the "Libera me" of the ''[[Requiem (Fauré)|Requiem]]''.<ref name=k35/>
;Prélude No 6 in E{{music|flat}} minor ''Andante.'' Fauré is at his most classical in this prélude, which is in the form of a [[canon (music)|canon]]. Copland wrote that it "can be placed side by side with the most wonderful of the Preludes of the ''[[The Well-Tempered Clavier|Well-Tempered Clavichord]]''."<ref name=copland/>
;Prélude No 7 in A major ''Andante moderato.'' Morrison writes that this prélude, with its "stammering and halting progress" conveys an inconsolable grief.<ref name=m13/> After the opening andante moderato, it becomes gradually more assertive, and subsides to conclude in the subdued mood of the opening.<ref name=m13/> The rhythm of one of Fauré's best-known songs, "N'est-ce-pas?" from ''[[La bonne chanson]]'', runs through the piece.<ref name=k36>Koechlin, p. 36</ref>
;Prélude No 8 in C minor ''Allegro.'' In Copland's view this is, with the third, the most approachable of the Préludes, "with its dry, acrid brilliance (so rarely found in Faure)."<ref name=copland/> Morrison describes it as "a repeated-note scherzo" going "from nowhere to nowhere."<ref name=m13/>
;Prélude No 9 in E minor ''Adagio.'' Copland described this prélude as "so simple – so absolutely simple that we can never hope to understand how it can contain such great emotional power."<ref name=copland/> The prélude is withdrawn in mood; Jankélévitch wrote that it "belongs from beginning to end to another world."<ref name=jank/> Koechlin notes echoes of the "Offertoire" of the ''Requiem'' throughout the piece.<ref name=k36/>
==For two pianists== [[File:Messager-by-fauré.jpg|thumb|right|upright|alt=pencil drawing of a balding, moustached man in left profile|Caricature by Fauré of his friend and co-composer of ''Souvenirs de Bayreuth'', [[André Messager]]]] ;Souvenirs de Bayreuth Subtitled ''Fantasie en forme de quadrille sur les thèmes favoris de l'Anneau de Nibelung'' ("Fantasy in the form of a quadrille on favourite themes from ''[[Der Ring des Nibelungen]]''"). Fauré admired the music of [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]] and was familiar with the smallest details of his scores,<ref name=nectoux39>Nectoux (1991), p. 39</ref> but he was one of the few composers of his generation not to come under Wagner's musical influence.<ref name=nectoux39/> From 1878, Fauré and his friend and ex-pupil [[André Messager]] made trips abroad to see Wagner operas. They saw ''[[Das Rheingold]]'' and ''[[Die Walküre]]'' at [[Cologne Opera]]; the complete ''Ring'' cycle in Munich and London; and ''[[Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg|Die Meistersinger]]'' in Munich and at [[Bayreuth Festival|Bayreuth]], where they also saw ''[[Parsifal]]''.<ref name="Jones 51"/> They frequently performed as a party piece their joint composition, the irreverent ''Souvenirs de Bayreuth'', written in about 1888. This short, skittish piano work for four hands sends up themes from ''The Ring''. It consists of five short sections in which Wagner's themes are transformed into dance rhythms.<ref>Wagstaff, John and [[Andrew Lamb (writer)|Andrew Lamb]]. [http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/18492 "Messager, André"]. ''Grove Music Online'', Oxford Music Online, accessed 14 August 2010 {{subscription}}</ref> The manuscript (in the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France|Bibliothèque nationale]], Paris) is in Messager's hand.<ref>Phillips, p. 103</ref>
;Suite d'orchestre, Op 20 Between 1867 and 1873, Fauré wrote a symphonic work for full orchestra. The piece was first heard in 1873 when Fauré and Saint-Saëns performed it in a two-piano version, but that transcription has not survived.<ref name=a3>Anderson (2000)</ref> [[Léon Boëllmann]] made a new transcription of the first movement in 1893.<ref name=a3/>
;Dolly Suite, Op 56 {{Main|Dolly (Fauré)}} [[File:Gabriel Fauré jouant à quatre mains avec Melle Lombard.jpg|thumb|left|alt=a young girl and an elderly man duetting at a grand piano|Fauré playing ''[[wiktionary:secondo|secondo]]'' with Mlle Lombard, a family friend]] The ''Dolly Suite'' is a six-section work for [[piano four-hands|piano duet]]. It was inspired by Hélène, nicknamed "Dolly", daughter of the singer [[Emma Bardac]] with whom Fauré was intimately associated in the 1890s. The opening piece was a present for Dolly's first birthday, and Fauré added the other five pieces to mark her subsequent birthdays and other family occasions. Unusually for Fauré, who generally favoured strictly functional titles, the movements of the suite have whimsical titles associated with Dolly and her family.<ref>Nectoux (1991), p. 62</ref>
Its six movements take about fifteen minutes to perform.<ref>Morrison, pp. 8 and 13</ref> The first is a Berceuse, or cradle-song. "Mi-a-ou", despite a title suggesting a cat, in fact represents the infant Dolly's attempts to pronounce the name of her brother Raoul; after "Le jardin de Dolly", the "Kitty Valse", again confounds its feline title, being a sketch of the family's pet dog. After the gentle "Tendresse", the suite ends with a lively evocation of Spain, which, Orledge notes, is one of Fauré's few purely extrovert pieces.<ref name=o95>Orledge, p. 95</ref>
;Masques et bergamasques, Op 112 From the orchestral suite drawn from his music for the stage presentation ''[[Masques et bergamasques (Fauré)|Masques et bergamasques]]'', Fauré made a transcription for piano duet, which was published in 1919. Like the orchestral suite, it consists of four movements, titled "Ouverture", "Menuet", "Gavotte" and "Pastorale".<ref>Phillips, p. 24</ref>
==Recordings== {{Listen|filename=Berceuse by Gabriel Fauré op56 no1.ogg|title=Berceuse from Dolly|description=The [[Berceuse]] from [[Dolly (Fauré)|Dolly]] by [[Gabriel Fauré]].|pos=right}} Fauré made [[piano roll]]s of his music for several companies between 1905 and 1913. The rolls that survive are of the "Romance sans paroles" No 3, Barcarolle No 1, Prelude No 3, Nocturne No 3, ''Thème et variations'', ''Valses-caprices'' Nos 1, 3 and 4, and piano versions of the ''Pavane'', and the "Sicilienne" from Fauré's music for ''Pelléas and Mélisande''. Several of these rolls have been transferred to CD.<ref>Nectoux (1991), p. 45.</ref> Recordings on disc were few until the 1940s. A survey by [[John Culshaw]] in December 1945 singled out recordings of piano works played by [[Kathleen Long]], including the Nocturne No 6, Barcarolle No 2, the Thème et Variations, Op 73, and the Ballade Op 19 in its orchestral version.<ref>Culshaw, John. [http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/December%201945/15/792329/ "The Return of Fauré"] ''The Gramophone'', December 1945, p. 15</ref> Fauré's music began to appear more frequently in the record companies' releases in the 1950s.
In the LP and particularly the CD era, the record companies built up a substantial catalogue of Fauré's piano music, performed by French and non-French musicians. The piano works were first recorded largely complete in the mid-1950s by [[Germaine Thyssens-Valentin]],<ref>Testament Records, SBT1400, SBT1215, SBT1262, and SBT1263</ref> with later sets being made by [[Grant Johannesen]] (1961),<ref>Initially Golden Crest LPs, reissued on VAI CDs ASIN: B00000G50B</ref> [[Jean Doyen]] (1966–1969),<ref>Erato, ASIN: B000001Z3C</ref> [[Jean-Philippe Collard]] (1974),<ref>EMI Records, catalogue number 5 85261-2</ref> [[Paul Crossley (musician)|Paul Crossley]] (1984–85),<ref>CRD Records, catalogue number 5006</ref> [[Jean Hubeau]] (1988–89),<ref>Erato Records, catalogue number 2564 69923-6</ref> and [[Kathryn Stott]] (1995).<ref name=m3/> Recital selections of major piano works have been recorded by many pianists including [[Vlado Perlemuter]] (1989), <ref>Nimbus Records, catalogue number 5165</ref> [[Pascal Rogé]] (1990),<ref>Decca Records, catalogue number 425 606–40</ref> and [[Kun-Woo Paik]] (2002).<ref>Decca Records, catalogue number 470 246–2</ref>

{{Infobox video game |title = Ride |image = Ride video game cover art.jpg |caption = |developer = [[Milestone S.r.l.]] |publisher = Milestone S.r.l. |designer = Irvin Zonca |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]]
[[PlayStation 3]]
[[PlayStation 4]]
[[Xbox 360]]
[[Xbox One]] |released = {{vgrelease|EU|March 27, 2015}}{{vgrelease|NA|October 6, 2015}} |genre = [[Racing video game|Racing]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Ride''''' is a [[motorcycle]] [[racing video game]] developed and published by [[Milestone S.r.l.]]. The game was released on March 27, 2015, in Europe, and on October 6, 2015 in North America for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], and [[Xbox 360]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pqube.co.uk/ride/#information|title=Ride - Information|work=PQube|accessdate=25 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bandainamcogames.com/game/ride.html|title=The Revolution is RIDE|work=Bandai Namco Games|accessdate=March 25, 2015}} == Development == On September 15, 2014, [[Milestone S.r.l.|Milestone]] announced the development of ''Ride'', a [[motorcycle]] [[racing video game]].{{cite web|url=http://ridevideogame.com/milestone-presents-ride/|title=Milestone Presents Ride|work=Ride|date=14 September 2014|accessdate=25 March 2015}} The studio had previously developed racing games within the licensed series ''[[World Rally Championship (video game series)|World Rally Championship]]'', ''[[Grand Prix motorcycle racing#In media|MotoGP]]'', ''[[Superbike World Championship#In other media|SBK]]'' and ''[[MXGP The Official Motocross Videogame|MXGP]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-01-18-milestone-picks-up-motogp-licence|title=Milestone picks up MotoGP licence|work=Eurogamer|date=January 18, 2013|accessdate=March 25, 2015}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 66/100{{cite web|title=Ride for PlayStation 4 reviews|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/ride|website=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=April 16, 2015}} |GMaster=64% |GTM=5/10 |IGN=70% |OPMUK=60% |OXMUK=6/20 }} Many reviewers described the game as "''[[Forza Motorsport (series)|Forza Motorsport]]'' with bikes."http://gamespew.com/2015/03/ride-game-review/http://www.isrtv.com/ride/ride-playstation-4-review/http://www.gamesradar.com/ride-review/ It was also noted as being more accessible to newcomers than other bike games. One complaint was the long loading times. The game reached number 10 in the UK PS3 sales charts, and number 13 in the PS4 charts.http://www.chart-track.co.uk/index.jsp?c=p%2Fsoftware%2Fuk%2Farchive%2Findex_test.jsp&ct=110042&arch=t&lyr=2015&year=2015&week=13 ==Sequel== ''Ride 2'' was released for PC on October 7, 2016, and for Xbox One and PlayStation 4 on February 14, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/brianmazique/2016/05/30/ride-2-announced-with-more-bikes-and-increased-customization/|title='Ride 2' Announced With More Bikes And Increased Customization|publisher=Forbes.com}} It features over 200 bikes from 15 different categories (as opposed to the 4 categories in the original game) with additional bike customization options. ''Ride 3'' is due for release in 2018. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Milestone S.r.l.}} [[Category:2015 video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Italy]] [[Category:Motorcycle video games]] [[Category:Racing video games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Xbox One games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Split-screen multiplayer games]] [[Category:Video games set in Argentina]] [[Category:Video games set in England]] [[Category:Video games set in Florida]] [[Category:Video games set in France]] [[Category:Video games set in Italy]] [[Category:Video games set in Japan]] [[Category:Video games set in Monaco]] [[Category:Video games set in Spain]] [[Category:Video games set in Wales]] [[Category:Video games set in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Milestone S.r.l. games]]

{{redirect|Scânteia}} {{italic title}} [[File:LogoScinteia.svg|thumb|300px]] [[Image:Scînteia 21 decembrie 1989.jpg|thumb|300px|The penultimate issue of ''Scînteia'', 21 December 1989. The headline reads: "''Comrade [[Nicolae Ceauşescu]]'s speech for radio and television stations''" (official answer to the outbreak of the [[Romanian Revolution]])]] {{Communist Romania}} '''''Scînteia''''' ("The Spark"; the [[Romanian alphabet|initial spelling]] of the name in [[Romanian language|Romanian]] was ''Scânteia'' until the change of the orthography in 1953, as it would have been again, the orthography having officially reverted in 1993) was the name of two [[newspaper]]s edited by [[Communist]] groups at different intervals in [[Romania]]n history. The title was a borrowing from the [[Russian language|Russian]] ''[[Iskra]]''.
==History== [[File:Miner reading Scanteia 1944.jpg|thumb|right|Miner reading ''Scânteia'']] The first paper of that name was edited by Romanian revolutionaries in [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Bolshevist Russia]], appearing throughout 1919 in the city of [[Odessa]].
''Scînteia'' reemerged as the official voice of the [[Communist Party of Romania]] on August 15, 1931, being published clandestinely in [[Bucharest]] until 1940 (when the hostility between Romania and the [[Soviet Union]] grew to a level where a crackdown on [[communist propaganda]] became imminent).
With Romania [[King Michael's Coup|withdrawing]] from the [[Axis Powers|Axis]] and joining the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] in August 1944, ''Scînteia'' was yet again being published, to remain the approved, sanctioning, body of communist politics. During [[Communist Romania]] (since early 1948), it was the barometer of policy changes, and the main medium through which the regime indicated its aims (for example, ''Scînteia'' served as the tribune for [[slander]] campaigns against intellectuals such as [[Tudor Arghezi]]). Moreover, (indicative of the relations between the official voice and other media), in 1961, August 15 was declared the ''Romanian Press Day''.
The headquarters of the paper were the main feature of the [[Socialist Realism|Socialist Realist]] ''Combinatul Poligrafic Casa Scînteii "I.V.Stalin"'', a name later reduced to ''Casa Scînteii'', after it dropped the reference to [[Joseph Stalin]] during [[De-Stalinization in Romania|De-Stalinization]]. Today, the building goes by the name ''[[Casa Presei Libere]]'' ("The House of the Free Press").
''Scînteia'' was accompanied by a youth version, one edited by the [[Union of Communist Youth]] (a branch of the Party that resembled the Soviet [[Komsomol]] up to a point). '''''Scînteia Tineretului''''' (or ''Scânteia tineretului''; approximately "Youth's Spark") began its edition in November 1944. It was also published under the names of ''Tinerețea'' ("The Youth") and ''Tînărul Muncitor'' (or ''Tânărul Muncitor''; "The Young Worker").
With the [[Romanian Revolution]] came the outlawing of all Communist Party institutions, including all its newspapers. ''Scînteia'''s assets were mostly taken over by the post-communist ''[[Adevărul]]''.
==Post-1944 editors in chief== *[[Miron Constantinescu]] (1944–1947) *[[Sorin Toma]] (1947–1960) *[[Theodor Marinescu]] (1960–1965) *Dumitru Popescu (1965–1968) *[[Alexandru Ionescu (journalist)|Alexandru Ionescu]] (1968–1978) *[[Constantin Mitea]] (1978–1981) *[[Ion Cumpănaşu]] (1981–1984) *[[Ion Mitran]] (1985–1989)
==Other staff== *[[Dic Baboian]] *[[Silviu Brucan]] *[[Constantin Chiriță]] *[[Leonte Răutu]]
==See also== *[[Eastern Bloc information dissemination]]
==References== *{{ro icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20071014181630/http://www.evz.ro/article.php?artid=208601 "''Scânteia'', ziarul cu două feţe" ("''Scânteia'', the Two-Faced Journal")], in ''[[Evenimentul Zilei]]'', 14 January 2006
{{Eastern Bloc media}}

(株式会社ソニー・ピクチャーズ エンタテインメント ''Kabushiki-Gaisha Sonī Pikuchāzu Entateinmento'') is a [[Japan]]ese [[film]] studio, based in [[Minato, Tokyo|Minato-ku, Tokyo]]. It is a division of [[United States|U.S.]] based [[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures Entertainment]]. [http://sonypictures.jp/corp/about/en/ About Sony Pictures Entertainment Japan][https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=22636854 Company Overview of Sony Pictures Entertainment (Japan) Inc.] It also uses the abbreviations as: '''SPE''' or '''SPEJ''' for operations. Sony Pictures Entertainment Japan and [[Mitsui & Co.]]'s joint venture AK Holdings is the majority shareholder of Japanese [[anime]] [[satellite television]] company [[Animax|Animax Broadcasat Japan]] and [[Kids Station]]. They have also distributed most of [[Sony Pictures]] films for Japan, as well as producing some [[Anime]] and Anime films as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/tag/sony-pictures-entertainment-japan/|title=Sony Pictures Entertainment Japan Archives|website=Animation Magazine}} ==Anime production== {{See|Aniplex}} {{Expand section|date=July 2012}} * ''[[Astro Boy (2003 TV series)|Astro Boy]]'' (2003) * ''[[Tokyo Godfathers]]'' (2003) * ''[[Paprika (2006 film)|Paprika]]'' (2006) * ''[[Ultraviolet: Code 044]]'' (2008) * ''[[Kurozuka (novel)|Kurozuka]]'' (2008) * ''[[Viper's Creed]]'' (2009) * ''[[Marvel Anime]]'' (2010–2011) * ''[[Iron Man: Rise of Technovore]]'' (2013) * ''[[Avengers Confidential: Black Widow & Punisher]]'' (2014) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.sonypictures.jp/ Official Website] *{{ann|company|5990}} {{Sony Corp}} [[Category:Sony Pictures Entertainment]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of Japan]] [[Category:Film distributors of Japan]] [[Category:Media companies based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Sony subsidiaries|Pictures Entertainment Japan]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 1984]] {{Japan-company-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} {{Infobox attraction | name = ''The Lego Movie: 4D - A New Adventure'' | logo = | logo_width = | image = The Lego Movie 4D - A New Adventure poster.jpg | caption = The promotional poster for ''The Lego Movie: 4D - A New Adventure''. | type = [[4-D film]] | theme = ''[[The Lego Movie]]'' | duration = 12 minutes | custom_label_1 = Produced by | custom_value_1 = Joshua Wexler
Leslie Barker | custom_label_2 = Directed by | custom_value_2 =[[Rob Schrab]] | custom_label_3 = Written by | custom_value_3 = [[Adam Pava]]
Rob Schrab | custom_label_4 = Opening Date | custom_value_4 = January 29, 2016 | custom_label_5 = Based on | custom_value_5 = {{based on|''The Lego Movie''|[[Phil Lord and Christopher Miller]]}} | custom_label_6 = Starring | custom_value_6 = [[A. J. Locascio]]
[[Elizabeth Banks]]
[[Alison Brie]]
[[Charlie Day]]
[[Nick Offerman]]
[[Patton Oswalt]] | accessible = | transfer_accessible = | assistive_listening = | cc = }} '''''The Lego Movie: 4D - A New Adventure''''' is a [[4-D film]] attraction based on ''[[The Lego Movie]]'' that premiered at [[Legoland Florida]] on January 29, 2016. ==Plot== Following the events of ''[[The Lego Movie]]'', Emmet, Wyldstyle, Unikitty, Benny and MetalBeard reunite to go to [[Legoland]]. However, they instead receive an invitation to go to a [[knock-off]] called Brick World. They then meet Risky Business, Lord Business' older brother, who tries to [[hypnotise]] them to perform in a ''Lego Movie'' live show. MetalBeard, Unikitty and Benny quickly go to their attractions, while Emmet goes with Wyldstyle to his. Emmet is unhappy, so Wyldstyle takes him to her attraction to cheer him up. Because of the extent, the group end up enjoying Brick World; Business takes advantage and sends his robots to hypnotise them with [[VIP]] [[wristbands]]. Emmet and Wyldstyle evade being hypnotised and discover Business' evil plans, as well as the audience. With the help of the audience, Emmet and Wyldstyle build a lemonade stand mech and save their friends. Business tries to escape, but a policeman stopped Risky from this, arresting him for making Brick World without permission. Emmet and Wyldstyle thank the audience before finally heading to Legoland with their friends. ==Cast== {{Main article|List of The Lego Movie characters}} * [[A. J. Locascio]] as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#Emmet Brickowski|Emmet Brickowski]] * [[Elizabeth Banks]] as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#Lucy "Wyldstyle"|Lucy "Wyldstyle"]] * [[Alison Brie]] as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#Princess Unikitty|Princess Unikitty]][https://movies.yahoo.com/blogs/movie-talk/superheroes-assemble-hilariously-lego-movie-trailer-214117774.html Exclusive: Meet Uni-Kitty, voiced by Alison Brie!] * [[Charlie Day]] as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#Benny|Benny]] * [[Nick Offerman]] as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#MetalBeard|MetalBeard]][http://collider.com/nick-offerman-lego-movie-interview/ Collider] * [[Patton Oswalt]] as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#Risky Business|Risky Business]] * David Burrows as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#Risky Business' Robots|Risky Business' Robots]] * [[Rob Schrab]] as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#Man of the Audience|Man of the Audience]] * Adam Pava as [[List of The Lego Movie characters#Police Man|Police Man]] ==Locations== ''The Lego Movie: 4D - A New Adventure'' is located in all Legoland parks and discovery centers, the St. Louis Zoo, Excalibur Las Vegas and an upcoming location of the 4-D theater in the [[Noah's Ark Water Park]], along with a location in [[Kennywood]] And Movie World Australia GoldCoast. ==Sources== *[http://www.comingsoon.net/extras/news/621979-lego-movie-4d] ==References== {{reflist}} {{The Lego Movie}} {{Legoland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lego Movie: 4D - A New Adventure}} [[Category:The Lego Movie|4D - A New Adventure| ]] [[Category:Legoland]] [[Category:Amusement rides introduced in 2016]] [[Category:Amusement park films]] [[Category:3D short films]] [[Category:4D films]] [[Category:2010s American animated films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Amusement rides based on film franchises|L]]

revision.text:
{{external links|date=May 2013}} {{italic title}} '''''The Runaway Bunny''''' is a [[concerto]] for violin, reader and orchestra by the contemporary American composer [[Glen Roven]], with text from the classic children's bedtime story ''[[The Runaway Bunny]]'' by [[Margaret Wise Brown]]. The concerto premiered at [[Carnegie Hall]] on April 29, 2008 with Roven conducting the [[American Symphony Orchestra]] with [[Glenn Close]] narrating.<ref name="Theater Mania">{{cite web|last=Lipton|first=Brian Scott|title=Glenn Close to Narrate Glen Roven's Runaway Bunny at Carnegie Hall|url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/04-2008/glenn-close-to-narrate-glen-rovens-runaway-bunny-a_13407.html|work=Theater Mania|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref>
== Composition history ==
Composer Glen Roven first conceived of writing a piece based on ''The Runaway Bunny'' after having seen the 2001 film ''[[Wit (film)|Wit]]'' based on the play of the same name by [[Margaret Edson]].<ref name="Roven's BLog">{{cite web|last=Roven|first=Glen|title=The Bunny, The Moon and Me|url=http://glenroven.blogspot.com/2010/04/bunny-moon-and-me.html|work=Glen Roven's Blog|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref> In the film, ''The Runaway Bunny'' is read to [[Emma Thompson]] by [[Eileen Atkins]]. Roven's first sketches were for a concerto for violin, singer and orchestra, however upon advice of the Israeli violinist Ittai Shapira, (for whom the solo violin part was originally written), it was decided to replace the singer with narration integrated into the overall musical structure. The work is in a single movement, with numerous tempo changes depicting the bunny's adventures.
According to the composer, ''The Runaway Bunny'' is similar to other classical concert works based on children's stories such as Prokofiev's ''[[Peter and the Wolf]]'', Kleinsinger's "[[Tubby the Tuba (song)|Tubby the Tuba]]", Chappell's "Paddington Bear's First Concert" or Poulenc's "L'histoire de Babar."<ref name="Classical BWW">{{cite web|last=Classical Music News Desk|title=Photo Flash: The Runaway Bunny|url=http://classical.broadwayworld.com/article/Photo-Flash-The-Runaway-Bunny-20080501|work=Classical Broadway World|publisher=Wisdom Digital Media|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref> The composer has subsequently arranged the orchestral score for [[piano trio]] and piano solo. All editions are published by Bill Holab Music.
This is the first concert piece to be based upon one of Margaret Wise Brown's popular children's tales.
=== The text ===
The text for Glen Roven's composition is drawn from ''The Runaway Bunny'', a 1942 picture book written by Margaret Wise Brown and illustrated by [[Clement Hurd]]. The plot deals with a little bunny who wants to run away, becoming variously a fish, a rock on the mountain, a crocus in a hidden garden, a bird, a sailboat, a circus acrobat, a finally a little boy until he resigns himself to just stay where he is and remain his mother's little bunny. Brown claimed that her inspiration for ''The Runaway Bunny'' came from "Chanson de Magali", a love song based on French Provençal folklore.<ref name=clack>{{cite web|last=Clack|first=George|title=The Strange, Wonderful Life of Margaret Wise Brown|url=http://www.317am.net/2011/12/the-strange-wonderful-life-of-margaret-wise-brown.html|work=3:17am|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref> The [[call-and-response (music)]] structure of Brown's text provides an emotionally compelling depiction of a small child's first burst of independence and a mother's affirmation of unconditional love.<ref name=Read>{{cite web|last=Cesaretti|first=Ms.|title=Module 1: The Runaway Bunny|url=http://readbeneaththecovers.blogspot.com/2012/12/module-1-runaway-bunny.html|work=Read Beneath the Covers|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref>
== Featured p-erformances ==
The broad popularity of Glen Roven's setting of Margaret Wise Brown's text has attracted many international celebrities<ref name=Playbill>{{cite web|last=Gans|first=Andrew|title=Tony Winner Catherine Zeta-Jones Will Narrate New Recording of "The Runaway Bunny"|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/169169-Tony-Winner-Catherine-Zeta-Jones-Will-Narrate-New-Recording-of-The-Runaway-Bunny|work=Playbill.com|publisher=Playbill, Inc.|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref> including:
*Shawn King, introduced by Larry King (performed during the Jerry Lewis MDA Labor Day Telethon, August 31, 2006)<ref>{{cite web|title=Video of Shawn King|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=97B0hNKhJ9Y|website=YouTube}}</ref> *Carnegie Hall World Premiere. [[Brooke Shields]] was announced,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hetrick|first1=Adam|title=Brooke Shields to Read "Runaway Bunny" at Carnegie Hall April 29|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/115664-Brooke-Shields-to-Read-Runaway-Bunny-at-Carnegie-Hall-April-29|website=Playbill|date=6 Mar 2008}}</ref> but was not able to perform the World Premiere. *[[Glenn Close]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lipton|first1=Brian Scott|title=Glenn Close to Narrate Glen Roven's Runaway Bunny at Carnegie Hall|url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/04-2008/glenn-close-to-narrate-glen-rovens-runaway-bunny-a_13407.html|website=TheaterMania|date=Apr 24, 2008}}</ref> *[[Kate Mulgrew]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Kate Mulgrew to read The Runaway Bunny May 9th, 2010 in Central Park|url=http://www.totallykate.com/poetrycd/rbunny.html|website=Totally Kate: the official website of Kate Mulgrew}}</ref> *[[Catherine Zeta-Jones]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://catherinezetajones.org/page/2/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128151416/http://catherinezetajones.org/page/2/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=November 28, 2011 |accessdate=March 19, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
== Recordings ==
*2008: Narrator: [[Brooke Shields]]; conductor: [[Barry Wordsworth]]; violin solo: Ittai Shapira; [[Royal Philharmonic Orchestra]] Sony 722855<ref name="BWW Classical">{{cite web|last=Classical Music News Desk|title=Shields to Narrate Roven's Runaway Bunny CD|url=http://m.bwwclassicalworld.com/article/Shields-to-Narrate-Rovens-Runaway-Bunny-CD-20060903|work=BWWClassicalWorld.com|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref> *2012: Narrator: [[Catherine Zeta-Jones]] (Piano Trio version); Trio 21 GPR11012<ref name=Wales>{{cite web|last=Turner|first=Robin|title=Catherine Zeta Jones to narrate US children's classic The Runaway Bunny|work=WalesOnline|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/lifestyle/showbiz/catherine-zeta-jones-narrate-childrens-2026059|accessdate=15 April 2013}}</ref>
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.gprrecords.com/catherine-zeta-jones-the-runaway-bunny/ GPR Records website] *[http://broadwayworld.com/article/Shields-to-Narrate-Rovens-Runaway-Bunny-CD-20060903# Broadway World.com review of Brooke Shields' narration with the RPO] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hLtXUgai3sk Promotional Video] *[http://glenroven.blogspot.com/2010/04/bunny-moon-and-me.html From the composer’s blog: The Bunny, the Moon and Me] *[http://everydayopera.com/author/glenroven/ interview with composer Glen Roven at Everyday opera] *[http://www.liherald.com/lynbrook/stories/Runaway-Bunny-Catherine-Zeta-Jones-jeffrey-biegel-Trio21-Lynbrook-pianist,42848 recording with Catherine Zeta-Jones] *[http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-runaway-bunny-paddington-bears-first-concert-tubby-the-tuba-mw0000753044 Review: AllMusic Guide] *[http://www.docstoc.com/docs/51466790/The-American-Symphony-Orchestra-Premieres-Glen-Rovens-The-Runaway American Symphony Orchestra Press Release]

revision.text:
{{cleanup-rewrite|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox video game | title = Yakuza Kenzan | image = Ryu ga Gotoku Kenzan! cover.png | caption = Japanese cover art | developer = [[Sega]] | publisher = Sega | series = ''[[Yakuza (series)|Yakuza]]'' | designer = [[Toshihiro Nagoshi]] | composer = | engine = | released = {{vgrelease|JP|March 6, 2008[http://www.gamespot.com/ps3/action/ryugagotokukenzan/ Ryu ga Gotoku Kenzan! @ GameSpot]}} | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | platforms = [[PlayStation 3]] }} {{nihongo||龍が如く 見参！|'''Ryū ga Gotoku Kenzan!'''|"Like a Dragon Arrives!"|lead=yes}}, unofficially known as '''''Yakuza Kenzan''''', is a ''[[jidaigeki]]''-themed spin-off game in the [[Yakuza (series)|''Yakuza'' series]]. The game was developed and published by [[Sega]] for [[PlayStation 3]].[http://ps3.ign.com/articles/819/819597p1.html Yakuza 3 is a PS3 exclusive] It was unveiled at the [[Tokyo Game Show]] 2007[http://www.jp.playstation.com/tgs2007/ps3/titles/sega_ryu.html PlayStation.com(Japan) TGS 2007 upcoming titles] and released in 2008. A second ''Yakuza'' series spin-off set in samurai era, ''[[Ryū ga Gotoku Ishin!]]'', was released in 2014 on both the PlayStation 3 and the [[PlayStation 4]] systems. ''Ishin!'' is set two centuries later than ''Kenzan!'', hence the plots are not related to each other since both games focus on different characters, the historical figures of [[Sakamoto Ryōma]] (1836-1867) and [[Miyamoto Musashi]] (1584-1645) respectively. ==Gameplay== ===Adventure=== The gameplay shows minimal evolution from the first two episodes except for the new item storage system which allows to access an unlimited amount of items from savepoints.[http://www.neogaf.com/forum/showthread.php?t=189397 Famitsu Article] However the graphical engine's improvement is obvious during the numerous real-time 3D cutscenes.[http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x8a8u8_yakuza-kenzan-cutscene-dintroductio_videogames Yakuza Kenzan! (opening cutscene)] ===Battle=== There are four fighting styles in the game; fists, one blade, two blades and [[two-handed sword|two-handed blades]]. There are also [[QTE]]-based special moves that the player can execute, known as 'heat action'. ==Plot== [[File:Kyoto gion02.jpg|thumb|The action moves from [[Kamurocho]] to [[Kyoto]]'s [[Gion]] district]] [[File:Kyoto3b.JPG|left|thumb|Landmarks such as the [[Kiyomizu Temple]] and [[Nijō Castle]] are modeled in the game]] ===Setting=== This spin-off is set in Kyoto during the [[Edo period]], in 1605. It is an account of the life of [[Miyamoto Musashi]]. The main adventure is completed with sidestories including minigames and a hundred "sub-stories".[http://www.jp.playstation.com/software/title/bljm60064.html PlayStation.com(Japan) Software Catalog - Ryu ga Gotoku Kenzan!] ===Story=== After being defeated by the [[Tokugawa clan]] at the historical [[Battle of Sekigahara]] which took place on October 20, 1600, Miyamoto Musashi retired from his great swordsman life to become a modest ''[[Bodyguard|yojimbo]]'' (bodyguard) in [[Gion]] (祇園), [[Kyoto]]. Five years after the battle, a little girl named Haruka comes to Gion seeking a local hitman known as [[Kazuma Kiryu|Kazumanosuke Kiryu]] which is actually Miyamoto's new identity. After eventually finding Kiryū, Haruka asks for him to assassinate an impostor pretending to be Miyamoto Musashi. At first, Kiryu refuses, then when the girl goes as far as becoming an indentured servant in an opulent ''[[oiran]]'' [[brothel]] in order to pay the assassination mission he accepts the one-[[ryō]] request. ===Characters=== [[File:Ryu ga gotoku kenzan event mode character.jpg|thumb|[[Cyberware Inc.]]'s facial scan technology was used with main characters and fully exploited on the Event Mode's high polygon models. Here character [[Gion Toji]] borrows actor [[Takashi Tsukamoto]]'s physical appearance]] This is the first game in the series where the games's main characters have their face modeled in 3D after their voice actors who are Japanese celebrities.{{cite web|title=セガ、PS3「龍が如く 見参!」完成披露会を開催発売日が2008年3月6日に決定|author=Reported by 福田柵太郎 Photo by 佐伯憲司|publisher=Game Watch|url=http://game.watch.impress.co.jp/docs/20071204/ryu.htm|date=2007-12-04|accessdate=2009-12-30}} [[Cyberware Inc.|Cyberware]]'s color [[3D scanner]] (model PS){{cite web|title=HP Workstation 導入事例紹介株式会社セガ 「龍が如く3」|author=Hewlett-Packard Japan|publisher=Hewlett-Packard|url=http://h50146.www5.hp.com/products/workstations/personal_ws/case_studies/sega_ryugagotoku.html|year=2009|accessdate=2010-01-17}} was used to analyze each actor's head & face in order to collect data on its shape and appearance, then this file was worked with the [[Softimage XSI]] 3D graphics application. *[[Takaya Kuroda]] as [[Kazumanosuke Kiryu]] (桐生 一馬之介) / [[Miyamoto Musashi]] (宮本 武蔵) *[[Shota Matsuda]] as [[Sasaki Kojirō]] (佐々木 小次郎) *[[Susumu Terajima]] as [[Itō Ittōsai]] (伊東 一刀斎) *[[Masaya Kato]] as Seijuro Yoshioka (吉岡 清十郎) *[[Takashi Tsukamoto]] as Gion Tōji (祗園 藤次) *[[Hiroki Matsukata]] as Mysterious Monk (謎の僧) *[[Naoto Takenaka]] as [[Marume Nagayoshi]] (丸目 長恵) *[[Aya Hisakawa]] as Yoshino Tayū (吉野 太夫) *[[Rie Kugimiya]] as Haruka (遥) *[[Yinling|Yinling of Joytoy]] as Libido Waterfall (滝の煩悩) ==Releases== ===Trial versions=== Two playable demos were released on January 7, 2008 via the Japanese [[PlayStation Store]]. The first demo included sandbox play, and the second had a collection of various combat and romantic gameplay segments.[http://kotaku.com/341754/yakuza-3-demo-hits-japans-psn Kotaku article] As part of the pre-ordering campaign, the Japanese first print was bundled with a limited item, a [[monography]] called ''Kamutai Magazine'' (March 2008 issue). Sony celebrated the Japanese release of the game with a 10,000 pieces limited edition Satin Silver 40GB model "PlayStation 3 Like a Dragon Kenzan! Pack" (龍が如く 見参！パック, ''ryu ga gotoku kenzan! pakku'') [[Stock-keeping unit|SKU]] including a "Rising Dragon" (昇竜, ''noburyu'') stickers set to customize the console case.{{cite web|title=『龍が如く 見参！』と新色サテン・シルバーのプレイステーション3本体を同梱した特別パックが発売|publisher=Famitsu website|url=http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1213425_1124.html|date=2008-02-05|accessdate=2009-12-29}} ===Asian and western markets=== The Japanese version was released on March 6, 2008 in both Japan[http://www.jp.playstation.com/software/title/bljm60064.html PlayStation.com(Japan - Software catalog - Ryu ga Gotoku Kenzan!)] and South East Asia,[http://www.play-asia.com/paOS-13-71-bp-49-en-70-2gfq.html Product page (BLAS-50044) at Play-asia.com] while Sony published it in South Korea on March 25, 2008 with a subtitled script book.[http://www.playstation.co.kr/ps_game/gam_main_view.sce?sid=1206&iPage=8 PlayStation Korea - PS3 software list] In late December 2009, commenting the opportunity of a western release, Sega Australia managing director Darren Macbeth said "there is nothing in the plan at this stage for Yakuza Kenzan. Right now we are focusing on the release of Yakuza 3. The feedback we get from this release will help us in making future decisions".{{cite web|title=Nagoshi talks Yakuza 3|author= Laura Parker|publisher=GameSpot AU|url=http://www.gamespot.com/pages/gamespace/updates.php?pid=950186&sid=6243556&skipmc=1&mode=previews|date=2009-12-28|accessdate=2010-01-01}} In March 2010, ''Yakuza 3'' had a western release as did in 2011 ''[[Yakuza 4]]''. Then again, in 2012, a second spinoff was also released abroad and localized as ''[[Yakuza: Dead Souls]]''. ===Soundtrack=== The ''Ryu Ga Gotoku Kenzan! Original Sound Track'' (HCV-381) album was published by [[Wave Master]] in Japan on March 6, 2008.[http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1213199_1124.html 新たなアプローチで作られた時代劇サウンド - Famitsu.com] Music was composed by [[Hidenori Shoji]], [[Hideki Sakamoto]], Hiroyoshi Kato, [[Keisuke Ito]] and Yuri Fukuda. This OST is noticeable for an exotic track, a flamenco piece titled ''Baile con la mariposa'' (Spanish for "Dance with the Butterfly") which is the theme for the duel between Musashi Miyamoto and Itto Ittosai. The track list has 31 titles (details are available below). {{hidden | style = border:1px dashed red; width: 50%; | headerstyle = background: #ccccff; font-size: 110%; | contentstyle = text-align: center; color:black; | header = Ryu Ga Gotoku Kenzan ! Original Soundtrack – track list | content =

Catalog: HCV-381}} Additional soundtrack includes two songs by [[Japanese hip hop]] artists [[Zeebra]] and [[Ketsumeishi]] ; Zeebra collaborated later with the ''[[Yakuza 4]]'' opening theme, ''Butterfly City''. *'''opening theme''': ''[[Bushido]]'' by Zeebra. Released in Japan by [[Pony Canyon]] (PCCA-02642) as a dual-disc single on March 5, 2008. First disc is a CD including the title track and an instrumental version plus a B-side ''Lyrical Gunman'' (Three Gunz Up Remix) featuring Rudebwoy Face and Chappa Ranks. Second disc is a bonus DVD with the music video for ''Bushido'' which includes cutscene footages from the game.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wh1tTdxCw1k ZEEBRA - BUSHIDO] *'''closing theme''': ''Life is Beautiful'' (ライフイズビューティフル, ''raifu izu byutifuru'') by [[Ketsumeishi]] from their 2007 album ''Ketsupolis 5'' published in Japan by [[Toy's Factory]]. ==Marketing== [[File:Yakuza kenzan screenshot one.png|thumb|[[Marume Nagayoshi]] versus [[Miyamoto Musashi]] (a.k.a. [[Kazumanosuke Kiryu]]) in Event Mode.]] ===Licensed products=== Clothes manufacturer Cropped Heads collaborated with [[Sega]] to produce licensed ''Ryu Ga Gotoku Kenzan!'' tee-shirts,{{cite web|title=Ｔシャツ : CROPPEDHEADS セガ コラボTee「龍が如く見参」　復刻版 : クロップドヘッズ |publisher=Repair Co. |url=http://www.repair-co.jp/shop/goods/1643/ |year=2008 |accessdate=2009-12-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090706140123/http://www.repair-co.jp/shop/goods/1643/ |archivedate=July 6, 2009 }} and Ace Cook produced ''Ryu Ga Gotoku Kenzan!'' cup noodles.{{cite web|title=焼きうどん「龍が如く」見参！|publisher=IT Media|url=http://www.itmedia.co.jp/news/articles/0801/17/news115.html|date=2008-01-17|accessdate=2009-12-29}} ==Reception== As of July 9, 2008, the game has sold 270,438 copies in Japan, according to ''Famitsu''.Weekly Famitsu, issue 1020{{cite web |url=http://www.japan-gamecharts.com/ps3.php |title=Sony PS3 Japanese Ranking |publisher=Japan Game Charts |date=2008-07-25 |accessdate=2008-08-03}} As a best seller in Japan, the game received a budget re-release under the [[PlayStation 3 the Best]] bargain collection on December 11, 2008.[http://www.jp.playstation.com/ps3/ps3thebest/2008.html#12 PlayStation.com(Japan) PlayStation the Best title list] It earned the Award for Excellence at the [[Japan Game Awards]] 2008,{{cite web|title=Japan Game Awards 2008 – Games of the Year Division|publisher=CESA|url=http://awards.cesa.or.jp/2008/english/award/year_09.html|year=2008|accessdate=2009-12-31}} and the Japanese video game magazine ''[[Famitsu]]'' reviewed it 37/40.[http://onaxis.blogspot.com/2008/02/yakuza-3-famitsu-review-of-3740.html onAxis article] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * revision.text:
[[File:Emilienne D'Alencon.jpg|thumb|160px|Émilienne d'Alençon]]
'''Émilienne d'Alençon''' (1869–1946) was a French dancer, actress and [[courtesan]].
==Biography==
Born in Paris, d'Alençon made her début at the [[Cirque d'été]] in 1889 before appearing at the [[Casino de Paris]], [[Théâtre Antoine-Simone Berriau|Menus-Plaisirs]], [[Folies Bergère]], Paris Scala and the [[Théâtre des Variétés]]. Among her earlier shows were ''Paris Boulevards'', ''Vénus d'Arles'' and ''Que d'eau Que d'eau''. She appeared in ''La Belle et la Bête'' at the Folies Bergères and she danced in the ballet ''The Red Slippers'' in London. She also performed as a dancer at the Paris Olympia in ''Faust'' and ''Grand Ballet Féerie''. In 1892, she came on stage as a snake dancer.<ref name=rosa>{{cite web|url=http://lebenundstil.blogspot.com/2012/11/die-rosa-kaninchen-der-emilienne.html|title=Die rosa Kaninchen der Émilienne d'Alençon|publisher=Leben & Stil |accessdate=1 March 2014 |language=German}}</ref>
Renowned as a courtesan, she was involved in a number of affairs including one with the industrialist [[Étienne Balsan]]. In 1895, she married the jockey Percy Woodland. Émilienne d'Alençon left the stage in 1906 and invested in [[horse racing]]. After losing her fortune on drugs and gambling in 1931, she was forced to sell her property and lavish furniture. She died in [[Nice]] in 1946.<ref name=rosa/>
==See also== *[[Women in dance]]
==References== {{Reflist}} 2. Chéri film.
==Literature== * Auriant (pseud. d'Alexandre Hadjivassiliou). Émilienne d'Alençon. Bruxelles: Éditions de la nouvelle revue belgique, 1942 * Ochaim B., Balk C.: ''Varieté-Tänzerinnen um 1900. Vom Sinnenrausch zur Tanzmoderne, Ausstellung des Deutschen Theatermuseums München 23. Oktober 1998 – 17. Januar 1999.'', Stroemfeld, Frankfurt/M. 1998, {{ISBN|3-87877-745-0}} * Dufresne Cl. Trois grâces de la Belle Epoque. Paris: Bartillat, 2003
{{Authority control}}
